{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 2015 Geldermalsen riot | partof = the [[European migrant crisis]] | date = 16 December 2015 | location = [[Geldermalsen]], [[Netherlands]] | type = [[Riot]]ing | perps = 14 arrested | weapons = Stones, fireworks, bottles | numparts = 2,000 local protesters | injuries = 3+ | dfens = Geldermalsen police }} The '''2015 Geldermalsen riot''' was a riot in the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] town of [[Geldermalsen]] on 16 December 2015 in protest of plans announced by the town council to construct a centre for 1,500 asylum seekers.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Migrant crisis: Dutch town riots over asylum centre plan|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35118496|publisher=BBC News|date=17 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title= Thousands riot in small Dutch town over plan for asylum-seeker centre |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/17/thousands-riot-in-small-dutch-town-over-plan-for-asylum-seeker-centre|work=The Guardian|date=17 December 2015}}</ref>
==Riots== On 16 December 2015, around 2,000 people in Geldermalsen protested and rioted outside the town hall as the town announced plans to build an asylum centre and accept 1,500 asylum seekers in light of the [[European migrant crisis]].<ref name=rt>{{cite web|title=Dutch protesters riot over plans to build refugee center in small town of Geldermalsen (VIDEO)|url=https://www.rt.com/news/326207-dutch-riot-geldermalsen-refugees/|website=rt.com|publisher=[[Russia Today]]|accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref>
Protesters attempted to storm the town hall while throwing beer bottles, fireworks and stones were thrown at it and police, as politicians discussed the plans. Several protesters, two police officers and a businesswoman inside the city hall suffered injuries during the riot.<ref name=rt /><ref name=dutchnews1>{{cite web|title=Woman hospitalised after she was hit by police in Geldermalsen|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2015/12/woman-hospitalised-after-she-was-hit-by-police-in-geldermalsen/|website=dutchnews.nl|publisher=Dutch News|accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref> Fourteen protesters were reported to have been arrested in the riots.<ref name=rt />
==Aftermath== Dutch politicians have characterised the riot as "unacceptable" and "un-Dutch".<ref name=rt />
It was later announced that the plans of constructing an asylum centre in the town had been scrapped, with the town council taking self-criticism for the speed of the decision process and the scale of the plans.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Geldermalsen refugee centre plan dropped in wake of riots|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2015/12/geldermalsen-refugee-centre-plan-dropped-in-wake-of-riots/|work=dutchnews.nl|date=23 December 2015}}</ref>
Protests and riots have erupted in several Dutch towns and villages since 2015 in protest of plans to take in record numbers of migrants.<ref name="YahooNews">{{Cite news|title=New riot in Dutch town against refugee centre|url=https://news.yahoo.com/riot-dutch-town-against-refugee-centre-212827300.html|publisher=Yahoo News/AFP|date=18 January 2016}}</ref> In January 2016, in [[Heesch, Netherlands|Heesch]], 1000 protesters rioted after plans to take in 500 asylum seekers in the town.<ref name="YahooNews"/>
==See also== *[[Timeline of the European migrant crisis]]

{{Discrimination sidebar}} {{Youth rights sidebar}} '''Adultism''' is ''"the power adults have over children"''.<ref name="Flasher1978">{{Cite journal | last1 = Flasher | first1 = J. | year = 1978 | title = Adultism | url = | journal = Adolescence | volume = 13 | issue = 51| pages = 517–523 | pmid = 735921 }}</ref> More narrowly, adultism is defined as ''"prejudice and accompanying systematic discrimination against young people"''.<ref>J. Gregoire/C. M. Jungers, ''The Counsellor's Companion'' (2007) p. 65</ref> On a more philosophical basis, the term has also been defined as ''"bias towards adults... and the social addiction to adults, including their ideas, activities, and attitudes"''.<ref name="Fletcher2013">{{Cite book | last1 = Fletcher | first1 = A. | year = 2013 | title = Ending Discrimination Against Young People | publisher = CommonAction Publishing | location = Olympia, WA }}</ref>
== Etymology ==
=== Coinage ===
The word adultism was used by Patterson Du Bois in 1903,<ref>Patterson Du Bois, ''Fireside Child-Study'' (1903) p. 17</ref> and appears in French [[psychology]] literature in 1929, describing the influence of adults over children. It was seen as a condition wherein a child possessed adult-like "physique and [[spirit]]", and was exemplified by, :A boy of 12 and a girl of 13 who had the spirit and personality of adults.... They were placed in institutions because of stealing and prostitution. These forms of precocity lead the individual into difficulties and should be recognized early in the development of the individual.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Courbon | first1 = P. | year = 1933 | title = Mental adultism and precocious growth of the personality | url = | journal = Annales médico-psychologiques | volume = 87 | issue = | pages = 355–362 }}</ref>
This definition was superseded by a late 1970s journal article proposing that adultism is the abuse of the power that adults have over children. The author identified examples of adultism not only in parents but in teachers, psychotherapists, the clergy, police, judges, and juries.<ref name="Flasher1978" />
=== Usage ===
Adultism is defined as the "behaviors and attitudes based on the assumptions that adults are better than young people, and entitled to act upon young people without agreement".<ref name="Bell1995">Bell, J. (1995) [http://www.youthbuild.org/site/apps/nlnet/content3.aspx?c=htIRI3PIKoG&b=4808015&ct=6640437 "Understanding Adultism: A Major Obstacle to Developing Positive Youth-Adult Relationships"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. [[YouthBuild USA]]. Retrieved 9/2/11.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gong|first1=Jennifer|last2=Wright|first2=Dana|title=The Context of Power: Young People as Evaluators|journal=American Journal of Evaluation|date=September 2007|volume=28|issue=3|pages=327–333|doi=10.1177/1098214007306680}}</ref> It is also seen as, "an addiction to the attitudes, ideas, beliefs, and actions of adults."<ref>[http://www.freechild.org/adultism.htm Introduction to Adultism]. [[Freechild Project]]. Retrieved 4/4/10.</ref> Adultism is popularly used to describe any [[discrimination]] against young people and is distinguished from [[ageism]], which is simply prejudice on the grounds of age; not specifically against youth. Adultism is ostensibly caused by fear of [[fear of children|children]] and [[fear of youth|youth]].<ref>Scraton, P. (1997) ''"Childhood" in "crisis"?'' Routledge. p. 25.</ref> It has been suggested that 'adultism, which is associated with a view of the self that trades on rejecting and excluding child-subjectivity, has always been present in Western culture'.<ref>David Kennedy, ''The Well of Being''(2006) p. 67</ref>
Fletcher<ref name="ReferenceA">Fletcher2013</ref> suggests that adultism has three main expressions throughout society: * '''Attitudinal Adultism''': Personal feelings, assumptions, and beliefs that form a person’s attitudes about young people. This is also called ''internalized adultism''. * '''Cultural Adultism''': The shared attitudes, including beliefs and customs, promoting the assumption that adults are superior to anyone who is not identified as an adult, simply because of their age. This is also called ''social adultism''. * '''Structural Adultism''': The normalization and legitimization of historical, cultural, institutional and interpersonal dynamics that routinely advantage adults while producing cumulative and chronic adverse outcomes for young people. This is also referred to as ''institutional adultism''.
A study by the Crisis Prevention Institute of the prevalence of adultism found an increasing number of local youth-serving organizations addressing the issue.<ref>Tate, Thomas F. and Copas, Randall L. (Spring 2003) "Insist or Enlist?: Adultism versus Climates of Excellence," ''Reclaiming Children and Youth: The Journal of Strength-based Interventions, v12'' n1. p 40-45.</ref> For instance, a local program in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]], describes the impact of adultism, which "hinders the development of youth, in particular, their self-esteem and self-worth, ability to form positive relationships with caring adults, or even see adults as allies", on their website.<ref>[http://www.youthtogether.net/mcm/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=39 Youth Together Glossary] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623094428/http://www.youthtogether.net/mcm/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=39 |date=June 23, 2007 }}. Youth Together. Retrieved 4/1/2008.</ref>
=== Similar terms ===
Adultism is used to describe the oppression of children and young people by adults, which is seen as having the same power dimension in the lives of young people as racism and sexism.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roche|first1=Jeremy|title=Children: Rights, Participation and Citizenship|journal=Childhood|date=November 1999|volume=6|issue=4|pages=475–493|doi=10.1177/0907568299006004006}}</ref> It is treated as a generalization of [[paternalism]], allowing for the broad force of adulthood beyond males, and may be witnessed in the infantalization of children and youth. [[Pedophobia]] (the fear of children) and [[ephebiphobia]] (the fear of youth) have been proposed as the antecedents to adultism.<ref>Fletcher, A. (2006) ''Washington Youth Voice Handbook'' Olympia, WA: CommonAction.</ref> [[Tokophobia]], the fear of childbirth, may also be a precursor; [[gerontophobia]], or its antonym, [[gerontocracy]], may be extensions of adultism.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}}
Similar terms such as adult privilege, adultarchy, and [[adultcentrism]] have been proposed as alternatives which are more [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphologically]] parallel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youthrights.org/threetypes.php |title=Three Types of Youth Liberation: Youth Equality, Youth Power, Youth Culture |first=Sven |last=Bonnichsen |publisher=National Youth Rights Association |accessdate=January 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231951/http://www.youthrights.org/threetypes.php |archivedate=February 1, 2011 }}</ref> Some activists alternatively call adultism "youthism," or "childism" equating it to [[sexism]] and [[heterosexism]].<ref>[http://www.zmag.org/dominickint.htm Youth Liberation: An Interview With Brian Dominick on Znet] {{webarchive|url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20070807052120/http://www.zmag.org/dominickint.htm |date=August 7, 2007 }}</ref> The opposite of adultism is [[jeunism]], which is defined as the preference of young people and adolescents over adults.
At least one prominent organization describes discrimination against youth as [[ageism]], which is any form of discrimination against anyone due to their age. The [[National Youth Rights Association]] argues that ageism is a more natural and understandable term than adultism and thus is more commonly used among the young people affected by this discrimination.<ref>[http://www.youthrights.org/forums/showthread.php?t=2188 Thread from National Youth Rights Association Online Forums re: Ageism vs. Adultism] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060824103141/http://www.youthrights.org/forums/showthread.php?t=2188 |date=August 24, 2006 }}. Retrieved 7/20/08.</ref> Advocates of using 'ageism' also believe it makes common cause with older people fighting against their own form of age discrimination.<ref>[http://oneandfour.org/archives/2005/10/ageism_vs_adult.html [[Alex Koroknay-Palicz]]'s blog] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060523205237/http://oneandfour.org/archives/2005/10/ageism_vs_adult.html |date=May 23, 2006 }}. Retrieved 7/20/08.</ref> However, a national organization called [[Youth On Board]] counters this, arguing that "addressing adultist behavior by calling it ageism is discrimination against youth in itself."<ref>Young, K & Sazama, J (2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: [http://www.youthonboard.org Youth On Board].</ref>
== Causes == In his seminal 1978 article, Flasher explained that adultism is born of the belief that children are inferior, professing that adultism can be manifested as excessive nurturing, possessiveness, or over-restrictiveness, all of which are consciously or unconsciously geared toward excessive control of a child.<ref>Flasher, J. (1978) "Adultism." ''Adolescence'' 13(51) Fal 1978, 521.</ref> It has been associated with [[psychological projection]] and [[Splitting (psychology)|splitting]], a process whereby 'the one with the power attributes his or her unconscious, unresolved sexual and aggressive material' to the child – 'both the dark and the light side...hence the [[Child (archetype)|divine child]]/deficit child'<ref>Kennedy, p. 64</ref> split.
Recently, theologians Heather Eaton and Matthew Fox proposed, "Adultism derives from adults repressing the inner child."<ref>Eaton, H & Fox, M. "Chapter 10: Transcendent Spirit: Child Honoring and Religion." in Cavoukian, R. (Ed) & Olfman, S. (Ed). (2006). ''Child Honoring: How to Turn This World Around''. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers/Greenwood Publishing Group.</ref> [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]] stated, "An understanding of adultism might begin to explain what I mean when I say that much of what is known as [[children's art]] is an adult invention."<ref>Holt, J. (Ed) ''Teach Your Own: The John Holt Book of Homeschooling''. Perseus Publishing.</ref> That perspective is seemingly supported by [[Maya Angelou]], who remarked: {{cquote|We are all creative, but by the time we are three or four years old, someone has knocked the creativity out of us. Some people shut up the kids who start to tell stories. Kids dance in their cribs, but someone will insist they sit still. By the time the creative people are ten or twelve, they want to be like everyone else.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Iraki, X.N. |author2=Mukurima, Muriuki |url=http://www.timesnews.co.ke/12jul06/nwsstory/opinion.html|title=Kenya Times News, Opinion--Education new vehicle of a class society |accessdate=2007-03-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070317003107/http://www.timesnews.co.ke/12jul06/nwsstory/opinion.html| archivedate= 17 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref>}}
==Evidence of adultism==
A 2006/2007 survey conducted by the [[Children's Rights Alliance for England]] and the [[National Children's Bureau]] asked 4,060 children and young people whether they have ever been treated unfairly based on various criteria (race, age, sex, sexual orientation, etc.). A total of 43% of British youth surveyed reported experiencing discrimination based on their age, substantially more than other categories of discrimination like sex (27%), race (11%), or sexual orientation (6%).<ref>Willow, C., Franklin, A. and Shaw, C. (2007). Meeting the obligations of the Convention on the Rights of the Child in England. Children and young people's messages to Government. DCSF.</ref>
== Classification ==
In addition to Fletcher,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> other experts have identified multiple forms of adultism, offering a typology that includes internalized adultism,<ref>[http://www.youthonboard.org/atf/cf/%7BDB81B10C-CCBB-46FE-BEF4-011DCFE93F33%7D/GetTheWordOut.pdf Get The Word Out!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926003153/http://www.youthonboard.org/atf/cf/%7BDB81B10C-CCBB-46FE-BEF4-011DCFE93F33%7D/GetTheWordOut.pdf |date=2007-09-26 }} Jenny Sazama (2004). p.12</ref> institutionalized adultism,<ref>Hernandez, D. & Rehman, B. (eds). (2002)''Colonize This!: Young Women of Color on Today's Feminism''. Seal Press</ref> cultural adultism, and other forms.
=== Internalized adultism ===
In a publication published by the [[W. K. Kellogg Foundation]], [[University of Michigan]] professor [[Barry Checkoway]] asserts that internalized adultism causes youth to "question their own legitimacy, doubt their ability to make a difference" and perpetuate a "culture of silence" among young people.<ref>[http://www.wkkf.org/pubs/YouthED/Pub564.pdf Adults as Allies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926003154/http://www.wkkf.org/pubs/YouthED/Pub564.pdf |date=September 26, 2007 }} (1998) WK Kellogg Foundation. Retrieved 4/1/2008.</ref>
"Adultism convinces us as children that children don't really count," reports an investigative study, and it "becomes extremely important to us [children] to have the approval of adults and be 'in good' with them, even if it means betraying our fellow children. This aspect of internalized adultism leads to such phenomena as tattling on our siblings or being the 'teacher's pet,' to name just two examples."
Other examples of internalized adultism include many forms of violence imposed upon children and youth by adults who are reliving the violence they faced as young people, such as [[corporal punishment]], [[sexual abuse]], [[verbal abuse]], and community incidents that include store policies prohibiting youth from visiting shops without adults, and police, teachers, or parents chasing young people from areas without just cause.<ref name="Bell1995" />
=== Institutional adultism === Institutional adultism may be apparent in any instance of [[systemic bias]], where formalized limitations or demands are placed on people simply because of their young age. Policies, laws, rules, organizational structures, and systematic procedures each serve as mechanisms to leverage, perpetuate, and instill adultism throughout society. These limitations are often reinforced through physical force, coercion or police actions and are often seen as double-standards.<ref>Males, M. (1997) ''Framing Youth: 10 Myths about the Next Generation.'' "Courts have explicitly ruled that policy-makers may impose adult responsibilities and punishments on individual youths as if they were adults at the same time laws and policies abrogate adolescents’ rights en masse as if they were children."</ref> This treatment is increasingly seen as a form of [[gerontocracy]].<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/0124/p25s04-usmb.html Monitor Breakfast with James Carville and Stanley Greenberg] "This is not class warfare, this is generational warfare. This administration and old wealthy people have declared war on young people. That is the real war that is going on here. And that is the war we've got to talk about." - James Carville</ref><ref>Gatto, J.T. (2002) [http://www.johntaylorgatto.com/underground/toc1.htm The Underground History of American Education] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210112502/http://www.johntaylorgatto.com/underground/toc1.htm |date=December 10, 2006 }} "Children allowed to take responsibility and given a serious part in the larger world are always superior to those merely permitted to play and be passive. At the age of twelve, [[Admiral Farragut]] got his first command."</ref>
Institutions perpetuating adultism may include the fiduciary, legal, educational, communal, religious, and governmental sectors of a community. [[Social science]] literature has identified adultism as "within the context of the social inequality and the oppression of children, where children are denied human rights and are disproportionately victims of maltreatment and exploitation."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lombardo|first1=Lucien|last2=Polonko|first2=Karen A.|title=Interdisciplinary Contributions to the Prevention of Child Maltreatment|journal=International Journal of Interdisciplinary Social Sciences|volume=4|issue=12|pages=89–112|url=http://iji.cgpublisher.com/product/pub.88/prod.945}}</ref>
''See also:'' {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Adoption]] of new parents * [[healthcare|Access to healthcare]]<ref>Institutionalized discrimination is also viewed as [[structural violence]]. See Kelly, P. "Fighting for Hope" (1984) for specific evidence of institutional adultism in healthcare, identified as structural violence. "A third of the 2,000 million people in the developing countries are starving or suffering from malnutrition. Twenty-five per cent of their children die before their fifth birthday... Less than 10 per cent of the 15 million children who died this year had been vaccinated against the six most common and dangerous children's diseases. Vaccinating every child costs £3 per child. But not doing so costs us five million lives a year. These are classic examples of '''structural violence'''."</ref> * [[Age of candidacy]] * [[Age of consent]] * [[Age of majority]] * [[The Mosquito|Age-based segregation]] * [[cohabitation]] with relatives/close friends * [[Compulsory education]] * [[Conscription#Ageism|The Draft]] * [[Condom#Laws and policies restricting condoms|Access to contraceptives]] * [[Curfews]] * [[Criminalization]]<ref>Giroux, H. ''Take Back Higher Education: Race, Youth, and the Crisis of Democracy in the Post-Civil Rights Era (2004).</ref> * emancipation laws in each state/country * [[Freedom of religion]] * [[legal drinking age|Drinking age]] * [[Overmedication|Over-medicating children]]<ref>Breeding, J. (n.d.) [http://www.naturalchild.org/guest/john_breeding.html Does ADHD Even Exist? The Ritalin Sham] Sunriver, OR: The Natural Child Project.</ref> * [[Military use of children|Child soldiers]] * [[Police#Difficult issues|Policing]] * [[Public school (government funded)|Public school]] choice * Voluntary [[employment]] when legal or approved by parent/the state * [[Voting age]] }} ''as well as:'' * [[Adolescence#Legal issues, rights and privileges|Legal issues affecting adolescence]] ''and'' * [[Total institution]]s
=== Cultural adultism === '''Cultural adultism''' is a much more ambiguous, yet much more prevalent, form of [[discrimination]] or intolerance towards youth.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} Any restriction or exploitation of people because of their young age, as opposed to their ability, comprehension, or capacity, may be said to be adultist. These restrictions are often attributed to euphemisms afforded to adults on the basis of age alone, such as "better judgment" or "the wisdom of age". A parenting magazine editor comments, "Most of the time people talk differently to kids than to adults, and often they act differently, too."<ref>[http://www.ru.org/83wright.html Treating children as equals.] Wright, J. New Renaissance Magazine (2001)."</ref> This summarizes cultural adultism. For examples see:
{{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Aesthetics]]<ref name="Leddy">{{cite journal|last1=Leddy|first1=Thomas|title=Aesthetics and Children's Picture-Books|journal=Journal of Aesthetic Education|date=Winter 2002|volume=36|issue=4|pages=43–54|doi=10.2307/3301567|jstor=3301567}}</ref> * [[Child abuse]] * [[Youth subculture|Academic misconceptions of youth]] * [[Youth culture|Commercialization]] * [[Content filtering|Online filters]] * [[Corporal punishment]] * [[Children's literature]] * [[Child labor]] * [[Teen idol|Mass marketing to youth]] * [[Peer pressure]] * [[Child prostitution]] * [[Sagging (fashion)#Controversy|Controversy over sagging]] * [[Scapegoat#Political/sociological scapegoating|Scapegoating]] * Stereotypes about [[List of youth subcultures|Youth subculture]] * [[Teen sex]] * [[Drinking age]] * [[Generation gap]] * [[poverty]] * [[unemployment]] gaps in ages 18 to 25 * [[Moralism]] * [[Mental illness]] * [[Runaway (dependent)|Runaways]] }}
== Results ==
=== Social stratification === Discrimination against age is increasingly recognized as a form of [[bigotry]] in social and cultural settings around the world. An increasing number of social institutions are acknowledging the positions of children and teenagers as an [[oppression|oppressed]] [[Minority group#Age minorities|minority group]].<ref>(2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: Youth On Board. p 95.</ref> Many youth are rallying against the adultist myths spread through mass media from the 1970s through the 1990s. <ref>(2004) [https://web.archive.org/web/20060718010357/http://www.movementstrategy.org/pdfs/MSMC.pdf "Making Space - Making Change: Profiles of Youth-Led and Youth-Driven Organizations"]. Movement Strategy Center. p 17. Retrieved 9/7/07.</ref><ref>Giroux, H. "The Abandoned Generation: Democracy Beyond the Culture of Fear" (2003).</ref>
Research compiled from two sources (a Cornell University nationwide study, and a Harvard University study on youth) has shown that social stratification between age groups causes [[stereotype|stereotyping]] and generalization; for instance, the media-perpetuated myth that all adolescents are immature, violent and rebellious.<ref>(2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: Youth On Board. p 94.</ref> Opponents of adultism contend that this has led to growing number of youth, academics, researchers, and other adults rallying against adultism and ageism, such as organizing education programs, protesting statements, and creating organizations devoted to publicizing the concept and addressing it.<ref name="Decision-Making. p 92">(2006) ''15 Points to Successfully Involving Youth in Decision-Making.'' Boston: Youth On Board. p 92.</ref>
Simultaneously, research shows that young people who struggle against adultism within community organizations have a high rate of impact upon said agencies, as well as their peers, the adults who work with them, and the larger community to which the organization belongs<ref>Zeldin, S, Kusgen-McDaniel, A, & Topitzes, D. [http://www.theinnovationcenter.org/pdfs/Youth_in_Decision_Making_Report.pdf "Youth In Decision-Making: A Study on The Impacts of Youth on Adults and Organizations"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819131311/http://www.theinnovationcenter.org/pdfs/Youth_in_Decision_Making_Report.pdf |date=August 19, 2006 }} (2001).</ref>
=== Cultural responses === There may be many negative effects of adultism, including [[ephebiphobia]] and a growing [[generation gap]]. A reactive social response to adultism takes the form of the [[children's rights movement]], led by young people who strike against being exploited for their labor. Numerous popular outlets are employed to strike out against adultism, particularly [[list of songs about school|music]] and movies. Additionally, many youth-led social change efforts have inherently responded to adultism, particularly those associated with [[youth activism]] and [[student activism]], each of which in their own respects have struggled with the effects of institutionalized and cultural adultism.<ref name="Decision-Making. p 92"/>
=== Academic developments === A growing number of governmental, academic, and educational institutions around the globe have created policy, conducted studies, and created publications that respond to many of the insinuations and implications of adultism. Much of popular researcher [[Margaret Mead]]'s work can be said to be a response to adultism.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mitchell|first1=Lisa M.|title=Child-Centered? Thinking Critically about Children's Drawings as a Visual Research Method|journal=Visual Anthropology Review|date=Spring 2006|volume=22|issue=1|page=68|doi=10.1525/var.2006.22.1.60}}</ref> Current researchers whose work analyzes the effects of adultism include sociologist [[Mike Males]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chu|first1=Julie|title=Navigating the Media Environment: How Youth Claim a Place Through Zines|journal=Social Justice|date=Fall 1997|volume=24|issue=3|pages=71–85|jstor=29767022}}</ref> and critical theorist [[Henry Giroux]]. The topic has recently been addressed in [[liberation psychology]] literature, as well.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Watts|first1=Roderick J.|last2=Flanagan|first2=Constance|title=Pushing the envelope on youth civic engagement: A developmental and liberation psychology perspective|journal=Journal of Community Psychology|date=August 2007|volume=35|issue=6|pages=779–792|doi=10.1002/jcop.20178}}</ref>
== Addressing adultism == Any inanimate or animate exhibition of adultism is said to be "adultist". This may include behaviors, policies, practices, institutions, or individuals.
Educator [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]] proposed that teaching adults about adultism is a vital step to addressing the effects of adultism,<ref>Holt, J. (2003) ''Teach Your Own'' Perseus Publishing.</ref> and at least one organization<ref>[http://www.youthonboard.org Youth On Board]</ref> and one curriculum<ref>Creighton, A. & Kivel, P. (1992) ''Helping Teens Stop Violence: A Practical Guide for Counselors, Educators, and Parents'' Hunter House.</ref> do just that. Several educators have created curricula that seek to teach youth about adultism, as well.<ref>Miller-McLemore, B. (2003) ''Let the Children Come: Reimagining Childhood from a Christian Perspective'' Josey-Bass.</ref> Currently, organizations responding to the negative effects of adultism include the United Nations, which has conducted a great deal of research<ref>[https://archive.is/20120915074105/http://www.unicef-icdc.org/cgi-bin/unicef/Lunga.sql?ProductID=384 The Evolving Capacities of the Child] UNICEF. (2005)</ref> in addition to recognizing the need to [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|counter adultism]] through policy and programs. The [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|CRC]] has particular Articles (5 and 12) which are specifically committed to combating adultism. The international organization Human Rights Watch has done the same.<ref>[http://hrw.org/reports/2005/us1005/6.htm The Difference between Youth and Adults] HRW online.</ref>
Common practice accepts the engagement of [[youth voice]] and the formation of [[youth-adult partnership]]s as essential steps to resisting adultism.<ref>(n.d.) [http://freechild.org/adultism.htm Adultism Resources] The Freechild Project website.</ref>
Some ways to challenge adultism also include youth-led programming and participating in [[List of youth organizations|youth-led organizations]]. These are both ways of children stepping up and taking action to call out the bias towards adults. Youth-led programming allows the voices of the youth to be heard and taken into consideration.<ref>https://freechild.org/adultism/</ref> Taking control of their autonomy can help children take control of their sexuality, as well. Moving away from an adultist framework leads to moving away from the idea that children aren't capable of handling information about sex and their own sexuality. Accepting that children are ready to learn about themselves will decrease the amount of misinformation spread to them by their peers and allow them to receive accurate information from individuals educated on the topic.<ref>http://taasa.org/lets-talk-about-sex/</ref>
==Criticism==
In its most extreme form, the target of the advocates of addressing adultism is "the more or less conscious, uncontrolled, and covert exercise of power over the child by the adult ... this wielding of power by adults"<ref>Alice Miller, ''The Drama of Being a Child'' (1995) p. 85</ref> ''per se''. Such an attack on ''any'' adult power may be fuelled by what has been called "the ''homunculus'' idea about children ... to many grown-ups a child is a Small Adult. They do not understand that a child carries different kinds of problems than an adult does".<ref>Eric Berne, ''A Layman's Guide to Psychiatry and Psychoanalysis'' (Penguin 1976) p. 103</ref>
In its milder form, "adultism is about the misuse of power and does not refer to the normal responsibilities of adults in relation to children".<ref>M.-N. Beaudoin/M. Taylor, ''Breaking the Culture of Bullying and Disrespect'' (2004) p. 9</ref> Therefore, "addressing adultism is not about reversing the power structure ... [or] completely eradicating it": rather, "shedding adultism involves a negotiation of decisions".<ref>Beaudoin, p. 129-30</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Angel Ivanovich Bogdanovich | image = BogdanovichAngel.jpg | caption = | birthname = Ангел Иванович Богданович | birth_date = {{Birth date|1860|10|14}} | birth_place = Vitebsk, [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1907|04|6|1860|10|14}} | death_place = Saint Petersburg, Russian Empire | occupation = literary critic, editor
political activist | years_active = 1980s – 1907 | spouse = Tatyana Bogdanovich (1872-1942) | website = | awards = }} '''Angel Ivanovich Bogdanovich''' ({{lang-ru|А́нгел Ива́нович Богдано́вич}}, October 14 [o.s. 2], 1860, [[Vitebsk Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] (modern [[Belarus]]) - April 6 [o.s. March 24], 1907, [[Saint Petersburg]], Russian Empire) was a Russian [[literary critic]], [[publicist]] and social activist, originally a [[narodnik]], later an active member of the [[Legal Marxism|Legal Marxists]]' political group.{{cite web | author = | date = 2000| url = http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/biograf2/1667|title = Bogdanovich, Angel Ivanovich| publisher = Biographical Dictionary| accessdate = 2014-01-13}}{{cite web | author =| date = 1969–1978| url = http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/bse/69920/%D0%91%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87|title = Bogdanovich, Angel Ivanovich| publisher = The Great Soviet Encyclopedia| accessdate = 2014-01-13}} ==Biography== Angel Bogdanovich was born in [[Vitebsk]], an heir to a noble family of the [[Poland|Polish]] and [[Lithuania]]n origins. In 1880 he enrolled into the [[Kiev University]]. As a student of the medical faculty, he became a member of a Narodnik political circle, was expelled and got deported to the [[Nizny Novgorod]] [[governorate]]. There he became friends with [[Vladimir Korolenko]] and started contributing to several [[Privolzhye]] journals. In 1887 he moved to [[Kazan]], there he edited the ''Volzhsky Vesnik'' newspaper. In 1893, now a [[Saint Petersburg]] resident, he founded there Narodnoye Pravo (People's Right) group and issued its political program in a brochure called ''Nasushchny Vopros'' (A Vital Question, 1894). In the mid-1890s Bogdanovich drifted away from Narodniks and became a member of the Legal Marxists group. In the early 1890s Bogdanovich regularly contributed to ''[[Russkoye Bogatstvo]]'', in 1894-1906 was a co-editor of and a key figure in ''[[Mir Bozhiy]]''. In 1906 ''Mir Bozhiy'' was closed but re-emerged as ''Sovremenny Mir'' (Modern World) and for a year Bogdanovich was its editor. Angel Bogdanovich died in Saint Petersburg on April 6, 1907. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Angel Ivanovich Bogdanovich}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bogdanovich, Angel}} [[Category:1860 births]] [[Category:1907 deaths]] [[Category:Russian literary critics]] [[Category:Russian editors]] [[Category:Narodniks]] [[Category:People from Vitebsk Governorate]] [[Category:Russian Marxists]]

{{Infobox political party | country = Denmark | name = Bornholm's Self-Government Party | native_name = Bornholms Selvstyre parti | party_logo = | colorcode = #008000 | leader = Tonny Borrinjaland | foundation = 1990s | Youth wing = | headquarters = | ideology = [[Separatism]] | seats2_title = [[Municipal council]]s | seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|2444|hex=#008000}} }}
'''Bornholm's Self-Government Party''' ({{lang-da|Bornholms Selvstyre parti}}) is a [[List of regional and local political parties in Denmark|local political party]] in [[Denmark]], which seeks to establish the independence or autonomy of [[Bornholm]], a small island in the [[Baltic Sea]] with a population of slightly below 40,000 people.<ref name="Population">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=24 September 2014|title=Der bor nu under 40.000 på Bornholm|url=http://www.jyllands-posten.dk/indland/ECE7049169/der-bor-nu-under-40000-pa-bornholm/|newspaper=[[Jyllands-Posten]]|language=Danish|location=[[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]]|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> Founded in the 1990s, the party has seen only minor successes, securing at most a few hundred votes at a time.
==History== Bornholm forms part of the ancient [[Lands of Denmark]], many of which were originally [[petty kingdom]]s or chiefdoms. It's the official stance of the Bornholm's Self-Government Party that the island was governed by its own petty king during the [[Viking Age]].<ref name="Sprogmuseet">{{cite web |url=http://sprogmuseet.dk/religion/biblijn-pa-borrijnholmsk/|title=Biblijn på borrijnholmsk|last=Dahl|first=Camilla Luise|date=12 February 2012|website=www.sprogmuseet.dk|language=Danish|publisher=Danish Language Museum|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> Regardless, Bornholm ended up hotly contested ground between different Danish factions, and the site of frequent battles. During the 16th century, starting 1525, the island was pawned to [[Lübeck]] for 50 years. From 1624 and on it had its own militia, ''Bornholms Milits''. Ceded to [[Sweden]] – together with [[Scania]], to which it belonged, along with other provinces such as [[Bohuslän]] – in the 1658 [[Treaty of Roskilde]], the island's population threw out the Swedes the same year. As a reward for returning to King [[Frederick III of Denmark|Frederick III]], Bornholm received a promise never to be ceded again. First occupied by [[Nazi Germany]] during the [[Second World War]], Bornholm saw heavy damage during the war, and was also [[Bornholm#Soviet Occupation 1945–1946|occupied]] by the [[Soviet Union]] until 1946.
Since the Second World War, Bornholm has seen a demographic decline, with a large drop in population numbers and birth rates, as well as employment issues.<ref name="Population"/> Due to these issues, and in response to the taxes paid by Bornholm to the central government, the master builder Tonny Borrinjaland founded Bornholm's Self-Government Party in the early 1990s. It has since participated in six municipal elections, gaining 299 votes in the [[Danish local elections, 2009|2009 elections]] and 190 votes in [[Danish local elections, 2013|2013]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bjerre Andersen|first1=Fredrik|last2=Ebdrup|first2=Niels|date=15 November 2009|title=Skæve og skægge - se valgets originaler|url=http://ekstrabladet.dk/nyheder/politik/article4195029.ece|language=Danish|newspaper=[[Ekstra Bladet]]|location=[[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Hansen|first=Bjarne|date=16 June 2012|title=Selvstyreparti søger partistøtte |url=http://www.bornholm.nu/?Id=43029 |language=Danish|newspaper=Bornholm.nu|location=[[Rønne]], [[Denmark]]|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Alsen Lauridsen|first=Michael|date=18 September 2014|title=Bornholmsk frihedskamp får næring fra Skotland|url=http://www.b.dk/nationalt/bornholmsk-frihedskamp-faar-naering-fra-skotland|language=Danish|newspaper=[[Berlingske]]|location=[[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
During the run-up to the September 2014 [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014]], the party expressed its sympathies for the cause of [[Scottish independence]], and stated that it had a lot to learn from the Scots. Party leader Borrinjaland also pointed to [[Malta]] and [[Singapore]] as two other models that Bornholm should learn from.<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=18 September 2014|title=Scottish vote inspires Bornholm's independence party|url=http://cphpost.dk/news/scottish-vote-inspires-bornholms-independence-party.10903.html|newspaper=[[The Copenhagen Post]]|location=[[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
Strongly in favour of preserving the endangered [[Bornholmsk dialect]], Borrinjaland has gone as far as to translate the [[New Testament]] to the local language. Commenting on his views regarding Bornholmsk, he stated: "Today, it is almost forbidden to talk Bornholmsk in kindergartens and schools on the island. That has Denmark with pure dictatorship taken care since many years. It's scandalous, I mean. Therefore, we must ensure that children learn the language, so they at least can choose whether to speak Bornholmsk or not."<ref>{{cite news |last=Krak|first=Nikolaj|date=23 December 2011|title=Bibelinj ee auersat tee ded bornholmska sprog|url=http://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/kirke-tro/bibelinj-ee-auersat-tee-ded-bornholmska-sprog|language=Danish|newspaper=[[Kristeligt Dagblad]]|location=[[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> Borrinjaland was also purportedly behind the launch of the [[flag of Bornholm]], a red and green [[Nordic Cross flag]] designed by a local painter and published in a local newspaper in 1975.<ref name="Sprogmuseet"/>

{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Guinea-Bissau.svg|150 px]]}}'''Corruption in [[Guinea-Bissau]]''' is among the highest levels in the world. In [[Transparency International]]'s Corruption Perceptions Index for 2014, it was ranked 161st out of 175 countries.<ref>{{cite web| title = CORRUPTION PERCEPTIONS INDEX 2014: RESULTS| work =Transparency International| url = http://www.transparency.org/cpi2014/results}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =CORRUPTION PERCEPTIONS INDEX 2013| work = Transparency International| url = http://www.transparency.org/cpi2013/results}}</ref> The previous year, it was at 163rd out of 177 countries. This marked a decline from its 2012 ranking, 150th out of 174 countries.<ref>{{cite web| title = CORRUPTION PERCEPTIONS INDEX 2012| work = Transparency International| url = http://www.transparency.org/cpi2012/results}}</ref> In 2013, Guinea-Bissau scored below the averages for both [[Africa]] and [[West Africa]] on the [[Mo Ibrahim Foundation]]’s Index of African Governance.<ref name=trans>{{cite web| title =OVERVIEW OF CORRUPTION AND ANTI-CORRUPTION IN GUINEA-BISSAU| work = Transparency International| url =http://www.transparency.org/files/content/corruptionqas/Country_profile_Guinea_Bissau_2014.pdf}}</ref>
The [[Heritage Foundation]] stated that corruption is characteristic of the Bissau-Guinean government and economy. Government mismanagement in Guinea-Bissau, according to Transparency International's 2014 report on the country, has “created an environment conducive to corruption on a grand scale.” There is a culture of impunity, and citizens have no right to access information.<ref name=trans/>
Much of the corruption in Guinea-Bissau is related to the fact that the country is a hub of international [[drug trafficking]].<ref name=free>{{cite web| title =Guinea-Bissau| work =Freedom House| url =https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2015/guinea-bissau}}</ref> “Abject poverty, state collapse, lack of means and endemic corruption,” states one source, “have made Guinea Bissau a heaven for the [[Colombia]]n drug lords.”<ref name=upenn>{{cite web| last =Horta| first =Loro| title =Guinea Bissau: Africa’s first narcostate| work =AFRICAN STUDIES CENTER - UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA| url =http://www.africa.upenn.edu/Articles_Gen/guinbisauhorta.html}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama greet His Excellency José Mário Vaz, President of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, and Ms. Rosa Teixeira Goudiaby Vaz.jpg|thumb|120 px|left|U.S. President Barack Obama and First Lady with President José Mário Vaz]] A Transparency International report on Guinea-Bissau notes the systemic instability and mismanagement of the government, as testified to by the fact that none of its presidents has ever completed an entire term in office.<ref name=trans/>
A former [[Portugal|Portuguese]] colony and “one of the most fragile states in Africa,” the nation won its [[Guinea-Bissau War of Independence|independence in 1974]] and has experienced several coups in the decades since then.<ref name=trans/>
In recent times, low economic growth has made it difficult for government officials to manage patronage networks and compensate cronies, thus feeding the growth of other forms of illegal self-enrichment, notably trafficking in drugs and [[Arms trafficking|weapons]]. These trafficking networks have made the country a hub for illegal commerce.<ref name=trans/>
There was some improvement in corruption between 2008 and 2011. Then, in 2012, the government was overthrown in a military coup, which brought an end to attempts to curb corruption and introduce other reforms. In 2014, voters elected [[José Mário Vaz]] to the presidency.<ref name=trans/>
==Drug trafficking== The country has been a drug-trafficking hub since around the turn of the 21st century, and many of its political and military leaders are deeply involved in the drug trade. Illegal narcotics from [[Latin America]] make their way to [[Europe]] by way of Guinea-Bissau,<ref name=trans/> which the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] (UNODC) considers the world's only “narco-state.”<ref name=spieg>{{cite web| last =Smoltczyk| first =Alexander| title =Guinea-Bissau a 'Drug Trafficker's Dream'| work =Der Spiegel| date =Mar 8, 2013| url =http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/violence-plagues-african-hub-of-cocaine-trafficking-a-887306.html}}</ref> As of 2007, Colombian drug cartels had, for the past three years, been using Guinea-Bissau as a major transit point for European trafficking. At that time, according to the US [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]], 800-1000 kg of cocaine were being flown nightly into Guinea-Bissau with an additional amount coming in by sea.<ref name=upenn/>
Latin American cocaine barons, ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' has explained, look for corrupt nations in convenient geographic locations, as ideal for trafficking drugs.<ref name=spieg/> Authorities in Guinea-Bissau who seek to curb the drug traffic lack the most basic equipment, such as vehicles and radios, and often have insufficient gasoline supplies.<ref name=upenn/> The country has no able or willing force for law and order, creating the ideal hub for narco-trafficking.<ref name=upenn/> It also has poorly enforced border, unmonitored airfields, and a weak civilian government. In addition, it virtually never extradites anyone, as evidenced by the case of murderer and hijacker [[George Wright (fugitive)|George Wright]], who after his conviction in the U.S. worked for years in Guinea-Bissau as a basketball coach.<ref name=spieg/>
==Government== The government's fiscal operations are characterized by a lack of transparency, of predictability, of budgeting control, collusion among government and key personnel, and of external controls over public spending. High-ranking officials in the country have accumulated “unprecedented wealth and influence” and enjoy a high degree of impunity.<ref name=trans/>
Political corruption consists largely of involvement in narcotics trafficking. This involvement, according to Transparency International, has overhauled patronage systems in Guinea-Bissau, ultimately lessening the state's role in corruption scheme, weakening the government as a whole.<ref name=trans/>
===President=== Under the constitution, the President has extremely broad powers, including lawmaking authority and the ability to appoint judges. This makes it easy for him to abuse his power and accumulate wealth at the expense of the people. Critics have argued that the president's power should be limited in specific ways while the prime minister's, [[National People's Assembly (Guinea-Bissau)|parliament]]'s, attorney general's, the judiciary’s powers are strengthened and reinforced. Critics have also called for a merit-based civil service.<ref name=trans/>
===Military, police, and security forces=== Guinea-Bissau's security and law-enforcement sectors are vulnerable to corruption and interference by politicians. Inadequate pay scales for members of the police and correctional services make them more vulnerable to corruption. Criminality and brutality among Bissau-Guinean security forces are well documented, as are cases of senior officials bypassing police authority by releasing prisoners and confiscating cocaine. An unclear situation involving jurisdiction results in institutional conflicts, especially where criminal investigations are concerned.<ref name=trans/>
Members of the police, security forces, and military are all involved in aiding and abetting the drug trade. For example, the military is engaged in leasing airbases and naval yards to drug traffickers, who have also rented islands to build front companies to mask plane movements. Also, the drug trade has helped breed a culture of intimidation and violence within the military.<ref name=upenn/>
===Judiciary=== The judiciary lacks adequate resources and training and also lacks independence. It does not pursue corruption charges. No one in the country has ever been prosecuted for or convicted of money laundering.<ref name=trans/> The public largely distrusts the nation's court system, due to the high costs of seeking justice and the lack of ethics, that leads people to solve disputes outside the legal system.<ref name=trans/>
Judicial corruption is a discouragement to business, according to roughly a quarter of companies that responded a [[World Bank]] 2006 Enterprise Survey.<ref name=trans/> A 2001 [[Amnesty International]] report suggested that the dismissal of several Supreme Court judges and clerks were related to judicial decisions that displeased the government.<ref name=trans/>
==Impact on business== In a 2006 World Bank survey, 44% of firms said that corruption was a major hinderance to business. In 2008, 27.6% of firms in Guinea-Bissau had been asked for bribes at least once; in Africa as a whole, the figure was 22.3%, and in the entire world, the figure was 17.4%. In the same year, fully 48.9% of firms in Guinea-Bissau said they had given “gifts” to win government contracts, as compared to 31.1% of firms in Africa generally. Almost two-thirds of firms in the country said they had been expected to bribe public officials in order to accomplish certain ends. For manufacturers operating in Guinea-Bissau, bribes could reach up to 4.4% of costs.<ref name=trans/>
==Anti-corruption efforts== Guinea-Bissau has few institutions or laws that are intended to fight corruption. Like other countries in Francophone Africa, it lacks a formal ethics code, has an inadequate number of external auditors, and has weak quality control.<ref name=trans/>
The Committee Against Corruption, created in 1995, was intended to address and prevent acts of corruption within the government and elsewhere.<ref name=trans/> The Court of Accounts, the leading audit institution, was introduced in 2006 to audit the accounts and budget of the Ministry of Finance.<ref name=trans/> Guinea-Bissau has ratified several United Nations Conventions combatting corruption as well as the African Union’s Convention on Corruption.<ref name=trans/> In 2008, Guinea-Bissau was found to be non-compliant with 34 of the 49 Financial Action Task Force (FATF) statutes, which cover such matters as due diligence and the criminalization of terrorism financing.<ref name=trans/>
In 2009, the country reformed its procurement system in conformity with West African Economic Monetary Union guidelines.This reform involved the establishment of a new regulatory body, the formation of a public procurement department, the institution of an audit unit to vet the central unit's procurement transactions, and the introduction of a new procurement infrastructure.<ref name=trans/>
A new system for managing public expenditure, instituted in or shortly before 2010, helped control government expenses by obliging every government office to submit an annual budget and progress reports to parliament.<ref name=trans/> As of 2011, the country planned a comprehensive set of anti-corruption reforms. After the 2012 military coup, however, reform efforts were ended.<ref name=trans/>
Some drug arrests have been made, including arrests of military officials, but defendants have not been successfully prosecuted. In March 2012, former Procurator General announced investigations into the murders of President [[João Bernardo Vieira|João Vieira]] and the Commander of the military, General [[Tagme Na Waie]], had halted due to difficulty in gathering evidence.<ref name=trans/>
In August 2015, President Jose Mario Vaz dismissed Prime Minister [[Domingos Simões Pereira|Domingos Pereira]] and the members of his cabinet, accusing them of corruption, nepotism, and obstruction of justice.<ref name=fox>{{cite web| title = Guinea-Bissau president dismisses government, accuses ministers of corruption, nepotism| work =Fox News| date =Aug 13, 2015| url = http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/08/13/guinea-bissau-president-dismisses-government-accuses-ministers-corruption.html}}</ref> The UN and GIABA helped establish Guinea-Bissau’s Financial Intelligence Unit, but its resources are too limited for it to be able to exercise its functions.<ref name=trans/>
===U.S. actions=== In April 2013, the US arrested the head of Guinea-Bissau's navy in international waters on drug-trafficking charges. He was receiving commissions of $1 million per ton for facilitating the shipment of illicit drugs into the US and Europe.<ref name=trans/>
In the same year, a US grand jury indicted the head of Guinea-Bissau's armed forces for trafficking cocaine and weapons.<ref name=trans/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Debt Conciliation Board, Government of Haryana |nativename =कर्ज निपटान बोर्ड, हरियाणा सरकार |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = 28 January 2007 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Haryana]] |headquarters = [[Chandigarh]] |coordinates = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Additional Deputy Commissioner |chief1_position = Chairman |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1= |website = [http://revenueharyana.gov.in/ revenueharyana.gov.in] |footnotes = }} The '''Debt Conciliation Board''' (DCB) is the independent organ of the [[Government of Haryana]] for the implementation of ''The Haryana Relief Of Agricultural Indebtness Act, 1989''.<ref>{{cite press_release | url=http://india.gov.in/allimpfrms/allacts/848.pdf | title=Govt. of India Press Release | accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref> It plays an important role in identifying the deserving candidates for providing relief and adequate benefits to them as per regulations.
==History== In 2007 Budget the central government passed the law of waiving agricultural loans to the tune of {{Indian Rupees}}60,000 crore, and to distribute this relief the debt conciliation boards were set up by the Haryana government. The board was formed on 28 January 2007 by Chief Minister of Haryana BS Hooda.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2008/20081113/haryana.htm#7 | title=The Tribune, November | accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref> It was formed to provide relief from huge debts to the poor farmers and labourers of Haryana. First it was decided to constitute a single board for the state of Haryana. But due to the presence of large population of benefitors it was decided to constitute this board in every district of Haryana.
==Hierarchy== The board in each district is presided by Additional Deputy Commissioner. The District Revenue Officer and a representative of the financial institutions are the other official members. Further there are two non official Government representatives from each district of Haryana. Non Official Members are as follows:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2007/20070129/haryana.htm#4 | title=The Tribune, 2008 | accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref>

==Provisions in law== The boards have been constituted under the Haryana Relief of Agricultural Indebtedness Act. Though the Act was enacted in 1989, the boards have been constituted to make the Act really effective. The boards have the jurisdiction to provide relief to debtors of not only a cooperative bank, cooperative society, nationalised bank or commercial bank, but also to the debtors of private creditors and money-lenders. Any debtor, who has paid more than double the principal amount, can approach the board. Section 3 (e) and 4 of the Act under which these boards were constituted provided rescheduling of the debts of farmers with regard to the repayment capacity of the debtor. Section 12 (5) provided that in case the debtor has repaid to the creditor an amount equal to or exceeding double the principal amount, or the debtor on being apprised of such findings pays an amount which makes total repayment equal to double the amount of principal, the board shall have the power to declare the debt as fully discharged.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2008/20080302/haryana.htm#2 | title=The Tribune, March | accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref>
==Criticism==
DCB has been often criticised for being ineffective in providing relief to the deserving candidates in Haryana. It has been alleged that the main reason behind the lackadaisical attitude of the government on this issue was that most political leaders had their own commission agent shops in various grain markets of the state and hence they acted as moneylenders to farmers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2008/20080302/haryana.htm#2 | title=The Tribune, Criticism | accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref>

The '''Easter Crisis of 1948''' was the fear that the [[Soviet Union]] or Soviet-aligned [[Communist]]s were planning an [[invasion]] or [[coup d'état]] in [[Denmark]]. Until this crisis, Denmark had tried to remain neutral between east and west, but the fear of attack from the east caused Denmark to align with the west.
