[[Popular Unity Candidacy]] | newspaper = | international = |affiliation1_title = |affiliation1 = | membership = | ideology = [[Catalan independence]]
[[Socialism]]
[[Feminism]]
[[Anti-capitalism]]
[[Ecologism]][https://www.eltemps.cat/article/3589/hem-danar-mes-enlla-per-arribar-a-sectors-on-no-arriba-lesquerra-independentista Hem d'anar més enllà per arribar a sectors on no arriba l'Esquerra Independentista]. [[El Temps]], 15 March 2018. | regional1_name = | regional2_type = | regional2_name = | student = | website = [http://laforja.cat/ www.laforja.cat] }} '''La Forja - Jovent Revolucionari''' (''The Forge - Revolutionary Youth'') is a [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] [[Catalan independence|Catalan independentist]] youth organization that acts in all the [[Catalan Countries]]. La Forja is part of the [[Popular Unity Candidacy–Constituent Call]] (CUP-CC)[https://www.catalunyapress.cat/texto-diario/mostrar/1078784/cup-decideix-aquest-diumenge-seu-suport-investidura-quim-torra La CUP decideix aquest diumenge el seu suport a la investidura de Quim Torra]. Catalunya Press, 13 May 2018. coalition and has very close ties with the political party [[Poble Lliure]].[https://www.eltemps.cat/article/4700/passat-present-i-futur-de-lesquerra-independentista Passat, present i futur de l’esquerra independentista]. [[El Temps]], 23 July 2018. ==History== ===Creation of Arran and split=== Before 2012 the Catalan independentis left had two youth organizations: [[Maulets (politics)|Maulets-JIR]] and CAJEI. The first one was founed in 1999 by the union of Maulets (youth wing of [[Catalunya Lliure]]) and the Catalan Revolutionary Youth (JIR, youth of [[People's Unity Assembly]]). The second one was created in 2002 by members of [[Endavant]]. Both organizations merged in 2012 creating [[Arran (organization)|Arran]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.setmanaridirecta.info/noticia/neix-arran-fruit-del-proces-d%E2%80%99unio-entre-maulets-cajei |title=Neix l'organització Arran, fruit del procés de confluència entre Maulets i la CAJEI |publisher=[[Setmanari de Comunicació Directa]] |date=4 July 2012 |accessdate=18 October 2018|language=ca |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120708014521/http://setmanaridirecta.info/noticia/neix-arran-fruit-del-proces-d%E2%80%99unio-entre-maulets-cajei |archivedate=8 July 2012}} Soon after the confluence, some [[Maulets (politics)|Maulets-JIR]] ex-members (especially those close to the [[Movement for Defence of the Land]]), started to consider that the leadership of the new organization was following the political line of CAJEI. These ex-members of [[Maulets (politics)|Maulets-JIR]] became involved in the creation of the youth of the [[Catalan National Assembly]] (ANC), the National Assembly of the Independentist Youth (ANJI). Due to this, they were threatened with expulsion from [[Arran (organization)|Arran]].[https://www.eltemps.cat/article/4700/passat-present-i-futur-de-lesquerra-independentista Passat, present i futur de l’esquerra independentista]. [[El Temps]], 23 July 2018. In 2014, groups of ex-Maulets created, along with other youth organizations, the Estudiants 9N movement, which organized a [[student strike]] to support the [[Catalan self-determination referendum, 2014|unofficial self-determination referendum]]. During the referendum campaign, some local chapters of [[Arran (organization)|Arran]] ([[Arbúcies]], for example) made posters asking to vote Yes, that the leadership of [[Arran (organization)|Arran]] ordered to retire. At the national assembly of that year, most members of [[Arran (organization)|Arran]] voted to expel those who participated in the [[Catalan National Assembly|ANC]], since that organization only fights for the independence of [[Catalonia]] and not the whole [[Catalan Countries]]. The vote was not valid because it did not reach the 70% of necessary quorum.[https://www.ara.cat/politica/Tres-decades-inici-combat-maulet_0_2094390543.html Tres dècades de l’inici del “combat maulet”]. [[Ara (newspaper)|Ara]], 24 September 2018. This vote caused a split in [[Arran (organization)|Arran]], with various local groups leaving the organization, including [[Mataró|Alt Maresme]], [[València]], [[Castelló de la Plana]], [[Badalona]], [[Cerdanyola del Vallès]] and [[Girona]][https://www.naciodigital.cat/noticia/90487/esperit/maulet/rebrota/arran L'esperit maulet rebrota a Arran]. Nació Digital, 12 July 2015. ===Creation of the Youth Assemblies for Popular Unity=== On 28 December 2015, the Assemblies of the [[Alt Empordà]], [[Maresme|Alt Maresme]], [[Badalona]], [[Berguedà]], [[Cerdanyola del Vallès]], [[Mataró]] and [[Sants]] celebrated the Founding Congress of the Youth Assemblies for Popular Unity (AJUP) in the town of [[Celrà]].[https://elmon.cat/politica/neix_la_coordinadora_d_assemblees_de_joves_per_la_unitat_popular_157801 Neix la coordinadora d'Assemblees de joves per la Unitat Popular]. El Món, 28 January 2016. The political declaration of AJUP declared the [[Catalan Countries|Catalan Countries independentism]], [[Marxist socialism]]{{dn|date=November 2018}}, [[feminism]] and [[ecologism]] as the main ideological lines of the organization. AJUP also considered the [[Popular Unity Candidacy|CUP]] as its "political reference".[https://www.llibertat.cat/2016/01/neix-la-coordinadora-d-assemblees-de-joves-per-la-unitat-popular-33789 Neix la coordinadora d’Assemblees de joves per la Unitat Popular]. Llibertat.cat, 28 January 2016. ===Foundation of La Forja=== In the second National Congress of AJUP, held on 3 and 4 February 2018 in [[Canet de Mar]], the organization was refounded as La Forja - Jovent Revolucionari. At the time of the foundation they were present in the ''[[Comarques of Catalonia|comarques]]'' of [[Alt Empordà]], [[Barcelonès]], [[Gironès]], [[Maresme]], [[Segarra]], [[Tarragonès]], [[Vallès Occidental]] and [[Terres de l'Ebre]].[https://www.llibertat.cat/2018/03/neix-la-forja-organitzacio-hereva-de-les-assemblees-de-joves-per-la-unitat-popular-ajup-41561 Neix ‘La Forja’, organització hereva de les Assemblees de Joves per la Unitat Popular (AJUP)]. Llibertat.cat, 14 March 2018. La Forja is part of [[Popular Unity Candidacy–Constituent Call]], Platform for the Right to Decide of the Valencian Country and the youth of the [[Catalan National Assembly]]. La Forja is also very close to [[Poble Lliure]] and the [[Intersindical-CSC]] trade union.[https://www.eltemps.cat/article/4700/passat-present-i-futur-de-lesquerra-independentista Passat, present i futur de l’esquerra independentista]. [[El Temps]], 23 July 2018. On 10 April 2018, two members of La Forja were arrested by the [[Mossos d'Esquadra]] in an operation against the [[Committees for the Defense of the Republic|CDRs]], both being released the next day.[https://www.vilaweb.cat/noticies/els-mossos-detenen-quatre-membres-dels-cdr-al-maresme-i-a-solsona-per-la-concentracio-el-30-de-gener-al-parlament/ Els sis membres dels CDR detinguts pels Mossos són posats en llibertat amb càrrecs]. [[Vilaweb]], 11 April 2018. Another 3 members of the organization are being investigated, accused of "damages and coercion", by the [[Ministry of Justice (Spain)|Spanish Justice]] since October 2018.[https://www.llibertat.cat/2018/10/citacions-judicials-als-militants-de-la-forja-de-girona-43365 Citacions judicials als militants de La Forja de Girona]. Llibertat.cat, 17 October 2018. La Forja has denounced these cases as part of a [[Political repression|repressive strategy]] against the [[Catalan independence movement]].[http://cerdanyola.info/politica/la-forja-denuncia-casos-de-repressio-al-valles/ La Forja denuncia casos de repressió al Vallès]. cerdanyola.info, 25 July 2018.[https://www.naciodigital.cat/noticia/163033/video/nova/canco/denuncia/repressio/primer/aniversari/1-o VÍDEO La nova cançó que denuncia la repressió en el primer aniversari de l’1-O]. Nació Digital, 17/09/2018.[https://www.diaridegirona.cat/girona/2018/10/18/jutjat-investiga-tres-activistes-mes/941065.html El jutjat investiga tres activistes més per coaccions i danys per les pintades a la subdelegació del govern]. [[Diari de Girona]], 18 October 2018. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Catalan nationalism}} ==External links== * [http://www.jnc.cat/ Official website] [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Europe]] [[Category:Youth organisations based in Spain]] [[Category:Catalan independence movement]] [[Category:Politics of Catalonia]] [[Category:Youth wings of political parties in Spain]]

{{Use British English|date=January 2013}} [[File:2016 Labour Party Conference, conference hall.jpg|thumb|The 2016 Labour Party Conference at [[ACC Liverpool]]]] The '''Labour Party Conference''', or annual national conference of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], is formally the supreme decision-making body of the Party. The conference is traditionally held on the final week in September, during the British [[party conference season]], when the [[House of Commons (United Kingdom)|House of Commons]] is in recess, and after the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] and [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] have held their conferences. Labour is one of few British parties to use their annual gathering for voting and policy resolution. The conference opens on a Sunday and finishes the following Wednesday usually with an address for the [[Deputy Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Deputy Leader of the Labour Party]] but some exceptions including 2016 have been made. This means that the Leader's address is usually held on the Tuesday beforehand.
==Conference decisions== In the [[United Kingdom]], each major political party holds an annual party conference during the [[party conference season]]. Conference is the supreme decision making body of the Labour Party.
===Delegates=== Delegates to the conference are elected by [[Constituency Labour Parties]], [[affiliated trade union]]s and [[socialist societies]]. Currently, affiliated trade unions hold 50% of the votes at the conference – down from 80% in the era before [[Tony Blair]]. Some 40% of the votes are wielded by the three largest trade unions ([[Unite the Union|Unite]], [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]], [[UNISON]]).
===Resolutions=== Resolutions for debate are put forward by CLPs and unions before the conference begins. In recent years, party members have had less say in what is debated at the annual conference, as the party leadership has tried to move policy-making increasingly into the new National Policy Forums, which meet in private.
===Role of the NEC=== The [[National Executive Committee]] leads the conference (although the details of the conference, including what is debated, are managed by the Conference Arrangements Committee) and if it does not agree with a resolution, the committee may put pressure on the backers to withdraw or ''remit'' it. ''Remittance'' means that the resolution's backers agree to "send back" the resolution to the National Executive so that it can consider the matter in more detail; this is viewed by some as a mere delaying tactic. The resolutions voted upon are normally ''composites'', meaning that they have been compiled by combining several resolutions put forward by different bodies into a single wording agreed beforehand.

==From 2000==
===2000 Brighton=== The international guest speaker was [[Nelson Mandela]], the former [[President of South Africa]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk_politics/2000/conferences/labour/default.stm |title=Conference 2000: Labour |publisher= BBC News |date=21 July 2002 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
===2001 Brighton=== The international guest speaker was [[Gerhard Schröder]], the [[Chancellor of Germany (Federal Republic)|Chancellor of Germany]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk_politics/2001/conferences_2001/labour/default.stm |title=Conference 2001: Labour |publisher= BBC News |date=18 February 2003 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
===2002 Blackpool=== The international guest speaker was [[Bill Clinton]], former [[President of the United States of America]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk_politics/2002/conferences_2002_/labour/ |title=Conference 2002: Labour |publisher= BBC News |date=24 January 2003 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
===2003 Bournemouth=== The international guest speaker to address conference was [[Hamid Karzai]], the first [[President of Afghanistan|President of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk_politics/2003/labour_conference/ |title=Conference 2003: Labour |publisher= BBC News |date=3 March 2004 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
===2004 Brighton=== The 2004 party conference was held in [[Brighton]] during the final week of September. Conference rejected a call for withdrawal from [[Iraq]], but accepted a resolution calling for renationalisation of the railways; the leadership declared that it would ignore this. The conference received some international glamour when it was addressed by the Irish rock star [[Bono]] who called for more action to combat the spread of [[AIDS]] and the debt crippling African countries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk_politics/2004/labour_conference_04/default.stm |title=Labour Conference 2004 |publisher= BBC News |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
Conference closed with the singing of ''[[The Red Flag]]'' and ''[[And did those feet in ancient time|Jerusalem]]''.
===2005 Brighton=== Over 600 people were held under the recent terrorism acts, including [[Walter Wolfgang]] an 82-year-old refugee from Nazi Germany who was arrested for attempting to re-enter the conference without a pass. None was subsequently charged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/over-600-held-under-terror-act-at-labour-conference-1-1098792 |title=Over 600 held under terror act at Labour conference |publisher= Johnston Publishing|work=Scotsman.com |date=3 October 2005 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk_politics/2005/party_conferences_05/default.stm |title=Conferences 2005 |publisher= BBC News |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref>
===2006 Manchester=== In 2006 the conference was held in [[Manchester]] at the [[G-Mex]] and Manchester International Conference Centre from 24 to 28 September. It was the first time since 1974 that the main Labour conference was not held at a [[coast|seaside]] town and the first time since 1917 the Labour conference had been held in Manchester. This followed Labour's Spring 2004 conference which was held at the G-Mex for the first time. The conference was Blair's last as leader after he stated this would be the case just before the conference and at the conference itself. The start of the conference was marked with [[protests against the Iraq War]].
Tony Blair, in his last speech to conference as Labour Party leader and Prime Minister, praised the work of the [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]], [[Gordon Brown]].<ref>{{cite news| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/5380004.stm | title =It's hard to let go, admits Blair | date = 26 September 2006| work =BBC News | publisher = }}</ref>
The conference was addressed in a joint session by Labour's [[Mayor of London]], [[Ken Livingstone]] and the [[Mayor of Los Angeles]] [[Antonio Villaraigosa]] on the subject of [[climate change]]. [[Bob Geldof]] and Monica Naggaga from [[Oxfam]] ([[Uganda]]) spoke together about the plight of Africa. The main international guest speaker was the former [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Bill Clinton]]. Another international visitor – but not a speaker to the conference – was [[Shimon Peres]], the former [[Prime Minister of Israel]].
St Johns C.E. Primary School's steel band also performed there before Tony Blair came on stage.
===2007 Bournemouth=== The 2007 conference was held in the [[Bournemouth International Centre]] from 23 to 27 September. The conference was the first with [[Gordon Brown]] as leader of the Labour Party and [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], and he laid out his plans for his premiership. It was a first conference for [[Harriet Harman]] as Deputy Leader and [[First Secretary of State]].
===2008 Manchester=== The 2008 conference was held between 20 and 24 September in [[Manchester]] at [[Manchester Central (Conference Centre)|Manchester Central]] (formerly G-Mex). The opening day of conference was moved from Sunday to Saturday to allow people who work during the week to attend. The Labour leader and Prime Minister, Gordon Brown, delivered his keynote address on 23 September.
===2009 Brighton=== The 2009 conference was held in Brighton from 27 September to 1 October 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.labour.org.uk/conference/ |title=Annual Conference 2011 |publisher=The Labour Party |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref> It is noted for a particularly impassioned address from [[Peter Mandelson]] given on 28 September in which he claimed that Labour was in "the fight of our lives" as the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|forthcoming general election]] approached.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8279053.stm|title= Election up for grabs – Mandelson|publisher= BBC News|date= 28 September 2009|accessdate=30 September 2009}}</ref> Gordon Brown gave his keynote address to the conference on the afternoon of 29 September, saying that Labour was "not done yet".<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8279701.stm|title= We're not done yet, insists Brown|publisher= BBC News|date= 29 September 2009|accessdate=30 September 2009}}</ref> Shortly afterwards Britain's biggest selling newspaper, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' announced that it would withdraw its support for the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and gave its backing to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article6855370.ece|title= Labour fails to conceal its anger after The Sun switches to support Conservatives|publisher=Times Newspapers Limited|work= Times Online|first= Phillipe|last= Naughton|date= 30 September 2009|accessdate=30 September 2009}}{{subscription}}</ref> Union leader and Labour supporter [[Tony Woodley]] responded to this by tearing up a copy of that edition of The Sun, telling the audience: "In Liverpool, we learnt a long time ago what to do. I suggest the rest of the country should do exactly the same thing";<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8282535.stm |title= Harman turns fire on Sun decision |publisher=BBC News |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref> in reference to the hostility felt in Liverpool towards ''The Sun'' newspaper following its controversial allegations about the behaviour of [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool FC]] supporters during the [[Hillsborough disaster]] 20 years earlier.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Owen Gibson |author2=Helen Carter |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/apr/18/hillsborough-anniversary-sun-newspaper |title=Hillsborough: 20 years on, Liverpool has still not forgiven the newspaper it calls 'The Scum'|publisher=Guardian News and Media |work=The Guardian|date= 18 April 2009|accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref> In the Prime Ministers Keynote Address Gordon Brown listed no fewer than twenty Labour Party achievements since 1997 and received an early standing ovation. The address would be his last as Prime Minister and for the Party would be their thirteenth and last party conference in government.
===2010 Manchester=== Shortly after losing the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]] to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]], the 2010 Conference took place between 26–30 September 2010 at [[Manchester Central (Conference Centre)|Manchester Central Conference Centre]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/sep/25/labour-leadership-result-candidates-manchester|title= Labour leadership result: candidates head to Manchester to hear verdict|date=25 September 2010|work=The Guardian|accessdate=7 October 2014|publisher=Guardian News and Media}}</ref> The conference started with the announcement of the results of the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2010|2010 leadership election]] and was [[Ed Miliband]]'s first conference as leader. In his first major speech as leader on 28 September, Miliband told delegates that his "new generation" would return the party to power.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11417906|title= Ed Miliband tells Labour: We're the optimists now|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|first= Emma|last= Griffiths|date= 28 September 2010|accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> The following day [[David Miliband]] announced he would not be serving in his brother's shadow cabinet, although he would continue as an MP.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11432762|title= David Miliband says he won't join brother Ed's team|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|date= 29 September 2010|accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref> Other highlights of the conference included activists condemning the [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|coalition government]]'s proposed public spending cuts as "obscene" on 27 September,<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11422247|title= Labour activists reject 'obscene' coalition cuts|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|first= Brian|last= Wheeler|date= 27 September 2010|accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref> and a close of conference address from [[Harriet Harman]] in which she told delegates that Ed Miliband would "fortify" the party.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11441103|title= Harriet Harman says Labour 'fortified' by new leader|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|first= Emma|last= Griffiths|date= 30 September 2010|accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref>
===2011 Liverpool=== The 2011 Conference took place in [[Liverpool]] from 25–29 September. It was the first time since 1925 that Labour had held its Annual Conference there. On 26 September delegates voted to scrap the tradition of [[Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (United Kingdom)|Shadow Cabinet]] elections.<ref>{{cite news|last=King |first=Victoria |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15054351 |title=Labour delegates vote to scrap shadow cabinet elections |publisher=BBC News |date= 26 September 2011|accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref> [[Ed Miliband]]'s keynote speech on 27 September suffered a five-minute blackout after all media communications were lost.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-news/local-news/2011/09/27/labour-leader-ed-miliband-s-keynote-speech-attacks-tories-and-promises-new-bargain-despite-broadcast-black-out-from-liverpool-100252-29495983/|title= Labour leader Ed Miliband's keynote speech attacks Tories and promises 'new bargain' despite broadcast black-out from Liverpool|publisher= Trinity Mirror|work= Liverpool Echo|date= 27 September 2011|accessdate=29 September 2011}}</ref>
=== 2012 Manchester === The 2012 Conference was held in [[Manchester]] from 30 September–4 October at Manchester Central Conference Centre. Labour Leader Ed Miliband's speech was the first by a Labour leader in around twenty years to be delivered without the use of an [[Autocue]], enabling him to walk up and down the stage during his speech while maintaining eye contact with his audience, replicating the style of [[David Cameron]] in 2005 when running for leadership of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/miliband-ditches-the-autocue-for-his-labour-conference-speech-but-who-planted-the-tree-8194625.html|title=Miliband ditches the autocue for his Labour Conference speech, but who planted the tree?|work=[[The Independent]] newspaper|author=Andy McSmith|date=2 October 2012|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref>
===2013 Brighton=== The 2013 Conference took place in [[Brighton]] 22–25 September at the [[Brighton Centre]].
===2014 London (Special Conference)=== A special conference was held at [[ExCeL London]] on 1 March to approve rule changes arising from former general-secretary [[Ray Collins, Baron Collins of Highbury|Ray Collins]] review of party reform. The changes included replacing the electoral college system for selecting new leaders with a "one member, one vote" system. Mass membership would be encouraged by allowing "registered supporters" to join at a low cost, as well as full membership. Members from the trade unions would also have to explicitly "opt in" rather than "opt out" of paying a political levy to Labour.<ref name=independent-20140228>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tony-blair-backs-ed-milibands-internal-labour-reforms-9161291.html |title=Tony Blair backs Ed Miliband's internal Labour reforms |author=Andrew Grice |newspaper=The Independent |date=28 February 2014 |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=guardian-20140301>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/2014/mar/01/labour-votes-on-membershipunion-reforms-at-special-conference-politics-live-blog |title=Miliband wins vote on Labour party reforms with overwhelming majority |author=Andrew Sparrow |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 March 2014 |accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=collins-review>{{cite report |url=http://action.labour.org.uk/page/-/Collins_Report_Party_Reform.pdf |title=The Collins Review Into Labour Party Reform |author=Ray Collins |publisher=Labour Party |date=February 2014 |accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
===2014 Manchester=== The 2014 Conference was held in [[Manchester]] from 21–24 September at Manchester Central Conference Centre. Ed Miliband was criticised by his own colleagues for failing to mention the deficit and immigration in his Conference address, despite having promised to do so in his pre-speech press release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/sep/24/ed-miliband-deficit-unite-len-mccluskey-labour|title= Miliband under fire from his own side for forgetting to mention deficit|work=The Guardian|author1=Nicholas Watt |author2=Patrick Wintour |author3=Rowena Mason |author4=Alan Travis |date=24 September 2014|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> It was Miliband's last Autumn Conference address as Labour Leader.
===2015 Brighton=== The results of the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2015|leadership]] and [[Labour Party (UK) deputy leadership election, 2015|deputy leadership]] elections were announced prior to the Annual Conference on 12 September at a special conference.<ref>{{cite web |URL=http://press.labour.org.uk/post/118867112494/timetable-announced-for-labour-leader-and-deputy |title=Timetable announced for Labour Leader and Deputy Leader elections |accessdate=28 May 2015 |date=13 May 2015 |website= press.labour.org.uk}}</ref> The 2015 conference took place in Brighton between 27 September and 30 September.<ref>{{cite web |URL=http://www.labour.org.uk/pages/faqs_annual_conference |title=Frequently Asked Questions |accessdate=28 May 2015 |website= Labour.org.uk}}</ref> The new Labour Leader, [[Jeremy Corbyn]], reinstated the use of the [[Autocue]], three years after it had been abandoned by Ed Miliband. It was the first time that Corbyn had used one to deliver a speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/Jeremy_Corbyn/11888959/Jeremy-Corbyn-starts-to-learn-to-use-an-autocue-five-days-before-his-big-conference-speech.html|title=Jeremy Corbyn starts to learn to use an Autocue - five days before his big conference speech|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Christopher Hope, Chief Political Correspondent|date=24 September 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref>
===2016 Liverpool=== {{Commons category|Labour Party Conference, 2016}} The 2016 Conference took place at [[ACC Liverpool]], it started on 25 September and ran until Wednesday 28 September. The result of the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|Leadership election 2016]] was announced the previous day with [[Jeremy Corbyn]] being re-elected.<ref>[http://www.labour.org.uk/pages/annual-conference-2016 Welcome to Annual Conference]</ref> The conference heard impassioned pleas for unity and a need for the party to gain power from Deputy Leader [[Tom Watson (Labour politician)|Tom Watson]] and Mayor of London [[Sadiq Khan]]. The party faithful were widely criticised for their apparent disunity among elected representatives but the gathering in [[Liverpool]] came together in harmony on many issues including opposition to plans for grammar school expansions, a 'hard brexit' and on accepting more unaccompanied child refugees into Britain.
===2017 Brighton=== The 2017 Conference took place at the 5,000 capacity [[Brighton Centre]] in [[Brighton]]. It ran from Sunday 24 September to Wednesday 27 September 2017, with the Leader's Speech taking place on the final day.
Jeremy Corbyn's leadership speech lasted 75 minutes and included a number of well received jokes, which came at the expense of both the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative party]] - specifically their reference to being unable to find a 'magic money tree', to fund new initiatives, prior to 2017 general election, only to find £1 billion to serve as the basis of a [[confidence and supply]] deal with the [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]] following the Conservative Party's re-election with a reduced majority<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/tory-dup-deal-agreement-full/|title=Tory-DUP deal: The agreement in full|last=|first=|date=26 June 2017|website=The Telegraph|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2017}}</ref> - and the [[Daily Mail]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2017/sep/27/jeremy-corbyn-conference-speech-labour-conference-2017-jeremy-corbyn-to-use-speech-to-say-public-services-and-businesses-must-be-more-accountable-politics-live?page=with:block-59cb9d13e4b050237a54f6fd#block-59cb9d13e4b050237a54f6fd|title=Labour conference 2017: Jeremy Corbyn's keynote speech – as it happened|last=|first=|date=27 September 2017|website=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2017}}</ref> In terms of policy, Corbyn pledged that a Labour government would give cities the power to bring in [[Rent regulation|rent controls]] and introduce restrictions on [[Gentrification|gentrification projects]], citing the then recent [[Grenfell Tower fire]].
During the course of the conference [[Jeremy Corbyn|Corbyn]] said that he was not planning a second referendum on [[Brexit]], but refused to rule out Labour backing one. He also said there were some “positives” from leaving the EU.
The Labour deputy leader, [[Tom Watson (Labour politician)|Tom Watson]], announced a number of policy plans, including: * Forcing gambling companies to pay a levy to fund research and NHS treatment to help problem gamblers deal with their addiction * Banning football clubs from signing shirt sponsorship deals with betting companies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2017/sep/26/labour-conference-2017-former-scottish-labour-leader-says-corbyn-partly-to-blame-for-brexit-politics-live?page=with:block-59ca8627e4b021792a4faa50#block-59ca8627e4b021792a4faa50|title=Labour conference: Corbyn says Brexit has some 'positives' and he's not planning second referendum - live|last=|first=|date=26 September 2017|website=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2017}}</ref> The conference also received attention as a result of a passionate speech delivered by [[Lauren Stocks]], a 16-year-old schoolgirl from [[Greater Manchester]], that subsequently went viral. Commentator quickly drew parallels with [[William Hague|William Hague's]] famous 1977 [[Conservative Party (UK) Conference|Conservative conference]], which he delivered when he was also 16. Stocks spoke about the toll that changes to the exams had taken on her and her classmates and argued that:<blockquote>There's a statistic we were shown when I was about 13 or 14 that told me 3 in 10 people in every classroom suffer with a mental illness. Now I'm going to be a bit frank here conference. That is b****cks! It's a good half ... I could've walked into any food tech, history, art, maths classroom and just watched seas of spaced-out, stressed-out, depressed kids, in a battlefield where they can't afford pens and paper! ... It is a disgusting sight and we cannot sit on our hands any longer!<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-41401263|title=Who's that girl? GCSE student wows at conference|last=|first=|date=1 October 2017|website=BBC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/that-bcks-watch-gcse-students-11229938|title='That is b****cks!' Watch GCSE student's furious rant about schools win a standing ovation at Labour conference|last=|first=|date=24 September 2017|website=Mirror|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2017}}</ref></blockquote>The conference hosted over 400 fringe events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.labour.org.uk/pages/annual-conference-2017|title=Annual Conference 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=UK Labour Party|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2017}}</ref>
===2018 Liverpool=== The 2018 Conference took place at the [[ACC Liverpool|Arena and Convention Centre Liverpool]] (ACC Liverpool)<ref>{{Cite web|title=Dods at Party Conference 2018|url=http://www.dodspartyconference.co.uk/labour-fringe-events|website=dodspartyconference.co.uk|publisher=[[Dod's Parliamentary Communications|Dod's Monitoring]]|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> with a capacity of 13,000 delegates at the event.<ref name="Sky-TWT2018"/> It was announced at the party that private property tenants would be given more protections, as landlords couldn't evict them without reason.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45621986|title= Labour plans to give tenants more power |author= |work= [[BBC News]] |date= 24 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> [[John McDonnell]] announced that workers in companies with more than 250 employees would become joint share holders in a scheme that companies would be forced to implement, with each employee receiving a payout at the end of each year.<ref>{{cite news | title = Labour conference: John McDonnell unveils shares plan for workers |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45621361 | work = [[BBC News]] |date= 24 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> [[Angela Rayner]] announced a range of education reforms: that Labour would scrap the [[Free school (England)|Free School]] program, democratise [[Academy (English school)|Academy schools]], give local authorities the power to take control of badly performing Academies and remove the ability to shape their own admission policies.<ref>{{cite news | last = Sabbagh | first = Dan | title = Labour vows to rein in academies and scrap free schools | url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/sep/23/ban-anonymous-accounts-angela-rayner-tells-social-media-firms | work = [[The Guardian]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref>
The prospect of a second referendum on the UK's relationship with the European Union was a heavily discussed topic at the conference. Both Leader Jeremy Corbyn and Deputy Leader Tom Watson had said should the conference vote for a second referendum they would support it.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Rawnsley | first1 = Andrew | last2 = Helm | first2 = Toby | title = Tom Watson: 'If Labour members call for a people’s vote on Brexit, then we must respect that' | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/sep/22/labour-tom-watson-interview-peoples-vote-brexit | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 22 September 2018 | accessdate = 24 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = PA | author-link = Press Association | title = Jeremy Corbyn would back second EU referendum if Labour activists support it | url = https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/jeremy-corbyn-would-back-second-eu-referendum-if-labour-activists-support-it-1-9362576 | work = [[Yorkshire Post]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> The motion was discussed by delegates on the Sunday, including MPs and representatives from [[People's Vote]] and other delegates, and after five hours they had written a two-paged motion stating that "If we cannot get a general election Labour must support all options remaining on the table, including campaigning for a public vote".<ref name="GU-McDnlref">{{cite news | last1 = Walker | first1 = Peter | last2 = Stewart | first2 = Heather | last3 = Elgot | first3 = Jessica | title = McDonnell: new Brexit referendum should not include remain option | url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/sep/24/mcdonnell-new-brexit-referendum-should-not-include-remain-option | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 24 September 2018 | accessdate = 24 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Labour to vote on 'keeping all options on the table' including backing second Brexit vote | url = http://www.itv.com/news/2018-09-24/labour-party-conference-brexit/ | work = [[ITV News]] | date = 24 September 2018 | access-date = 24 September 2018}}</ref> The vote on motion took place on the Tuesday.
Party delegates voted on the Member of Parliament reselection process. They lowered the threshold required of local branches and local union branches to express disatifaction in an MP's performance from 50% to 33%.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Elgot | first1 = Jessica | last2 = Syal | first2 = Rajeev |title= Labour members in open revolt at union-backed party rule changes |url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/sep/23/labour-members-in-open-revolt-at-union-backed-party-reforms |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref>
Fringe Events also took place at the conference: * The World Transformed: A four-day festival of music and politics organised by [[Momentum (organisation)|Momentum]] with the capacity for 10,000 people to attend.<ref name="Sky-TWT2018">{{cite web | last = Allegretti | first = Aubrey |title= The World Transformed: How Momentum festival is challenging for the 'mainstream' Labour conference |url= https://news.sky.com/story/the-world-transformed-how-momentum-festival-is-challenging-for-the-mainstream-labour-conference-11505328 |publisher= [[Sky News]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> Speakers include [[2017 French presidential election|2017 French presidential candidate]] [[Jean-Luc Mélenchon]] as a key-note speaker,<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/23/jean-luc-melenchon-to-speak-at-pro-corbyn-event-in-liverpool |title= Jean-Luc Mélenchon to speak at pro-Corbyn event in Liverpool |author= Angelique Chrisafis |publisher= [[The Guardian]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> as well as Jeremy Corbyn, [[Katja Kipping]] (leader of [[The Left (Germany)|Die Linke]]), [[Ralf Stegner]] ([[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]]), [[Zitto Kabwe]] (leader of [[Alliance for Change and Transparency]]) and [[Ash Sarkar]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Rodgers | first = Sienna |title= The World Transformed reveals full line-up ahead of Labour conference |url= https://labourlist.org/2018/08/the-world-transformed-reveals-full-line-up-ahead-of-labour-conference/ |publisher= [[LabourList]] |date= 8 August 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> * Councils against Austerity: A group of 24 Labour council leaders and 12 local Labour group leaders, who signed an open letter sent to [[Prime Minister]] Theresa May criticising austerity's effect on Local Government, organised an event at the conference.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://labourlist.org/2018/09/local-labour-leaders-attack-tory-austerity-with-new-campaign/ |title= Local Labour leaders attack Tory austerity with new campaign |author= |publisher= [[LabourList]] |date= 19 September 2018 |accessdate= 24 September 2018}}</ref> * Real Britain: an event hosted by [[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]] it was chaired by journalist [[Kevin Maguire (journalist)|Kevin Maguire]] and had speakers such as John McDonnell, Len McCluskey and former footballer [[Neville Southall]].<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Bartlett | first1 = Nicola |title= Real Britain Fringe 2018: The Mirror takes powerful stories from Wigan Pier project to Labour Party Conference |url= https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/real-britain-fringe-2017-mirror-13295129 |work= [[Daily Mirror]] | publisher = [[Reach plc]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 25 September 2018}}</ref> At this event McCluskey stated [[Unite the Union|Unite]]'s interest in supporting [[Labour Party in Northern Ireland|Labour Party candidates in Northern Ireland]], instead of the [[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/staggers/2018/09/will-labour-run-northern-ireland |title= Will Labour run in Northern Ireland? |author= Patrick Maguire |publisher= [[The New Statesman]] |date= 23 September 2018 |accessdate= 26 September 2018}}</ref>

'''Language nest'''s, an [[language immersion|immersion]]-based approach to [[language revitalization]], originated in [[New Zealand]] in 1982 as a part of the [[Māori language revival]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/livingthelanguage/2012/04/2012416141630195978.html|title = New Zealand: The Maori|date = July 17, 2014|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Al Jazeera|last = |first = }}</ref> The term "language nest" is a translation of the Māori phrase [[Māori language revival#K.C5.8Dhanga reo|''kōhanga reo'']].
In a language nest, older speakers of the language take part in [[early childhood education|early-childhood education]] with a view to improving intergenerational language transference.
== In New Zealand == The first ''kōhanga reo'' was founded in [[Wainuiomata]] in 1982, and was followed by the establishment of primary schools and secondary schools ([[Kura Kaupapa Māori]]) where [[Māori language|Māori]] is the primary language of instruction.
According to Al Jazeera, the percentage of Maori people speaking the language has increased by a few percentage points from the early 1980s to 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/livingthelanguage/2012/04/2012416141630195978.html|title = New Zealand: The Maori|date = July 17, 2014|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Al Jazeera|last = |first = }}</ref> Linguist Christopher Moseley says that this statistic is "quite encouraging" because "compared to how quickly a language can disappear, in just one generation in extreme cases, the figures are good."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/livingthelanguage/2012/04/2012416141630195978.html|title = New Zealand: The Maori|date = July 17, 2014|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Al Jazeera|last = |first = }}</ref>
== In the United States == In [[Hawaii]], the [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian-language]] equivalent, the [[Pūnana Leo]], has been running for 24 years<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.culturalsurvival.org/publications/cultural-survival-quarterly/united-states/aha-p-nana-leo|title = ‘Aha Pūnana Leo|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = Cultural Survival|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and has also been successful in producing first-language speakers of Hawaiian.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ahapunanaleo.org/index.php?/about/a_timeline_of_revitalization/|title = A Timeline of Revitalization|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = Aha Punana Leo|last = |first = }}</ref>
In [[Minnesota]], the Enweyang Ojibwe Language Nest, started in 2009. In collaboration with UMD's College of Education and Human Services Professionals and Eni-gikendaasoyang, the Center for Indigenous Knowledge and [[Language revitalization|Language Revitalization]], the program targets 4-5 year olds in a half day session in the [[Duluth, Minnesota|Duluth]] area.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://d.umn.edu/external-affairs/homepage/10/languagenest.html|title=Enweyang Ojibwe Language Nest|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Minnesota Duluth|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref>
In [[North Dakota]], Lakȟól’yapi Wahóȟpi, the Lakota Language Immersion Nest, opened on September 12, 2012. Full day schooling aimed at 3-year olds, with parents also receiving training to encourage at home efforts is key to this program. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://lastrealindians.com/lakota-language-immersion-nest/|title=Lakota Language Immersion Nest|date=2012-09-10|work=Last Real Indians|access-date=2017-03-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
== In Australia == In August 2009, the [[Australian government]] pledged to pilot language nests as part of its National Indigenous Languages Policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arts.gov.au/indigenous/languages_policy|title=Indigenous Languages Policy}}</ref> The first of five Aboriginal language and culture nests in [[New South Wales]] launched in 2013, although these are government service delivery centres and not immersion pre-schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://theconversation.com/language-nests-a-way-to-revive-indigenous-languages-at-risk-19824|title = Language Nests: a way to revive Indigenous languages at risk|date = November 12, 2013|accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = The Conversation|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Aboriginal Language and Culture Nests - Aboriginal Affairs|url = http://www.aboriginalaffairs.nsw.gov.au/aboriginal-language-and-culture-nests/|accessdate = 2015-09-10}}</ref> The [[Miriwoong]] Language Nest has been running in [[Kununurra]] since early 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://soundcloud.com/abcwa/theyre-just-so-proud-to-see-their-grandchildren-learning-their-language|title = They're just so proud to see their grandchildren learning their language|date = |accessdate = March 30, 2015|website = |publisher = ABC Kimberley|last = |first = }}</ref> with over 300 children attending per week.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mirima.org.au/language-nest.html|title = Language Nest|date = |accessdate = March 30, 2015|website = |publisher = Mirima Dawang Woorlab-gerring Language and Culture Centre|last = |first = }}</ref>
== In Canada == A study in 2004 reported on two language nests in British Columbia: a ''Cseyseten'' ("language nest") at [[Adam’s Lake]] in the [[Secwepemc]] language, and a ''Clao7alcw'' ("Raven’s nest") at [[Lil’wat Nation]] in the [[Lillooet language|Lil’wat]] language written about by [[Onowa McIvor]] for her Master's thesis.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fpcc.ca/files/PDF/language-nest-programs_in_BC.pdf|title = Language Nest programs in BC (MA Thesis)|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = |last = McIvor|first = Onowa}}</ref>
The [[First Peoples' Cultural Council]] in Canada provides grants to [[First Nations]] communities in [[British Columbia]] as part of the Pre-School Language Nest Program.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fpcc.ca/language/Programs/Language-nest.aspx|title = Pre-School Language Nest Program|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = |publisher = First People's Cultural Council|last = |first = }}</ref>
In the [[Northwest Territories]], there are language nests for each of the official Aboriginal languages, with more than 20 language nests in total.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ece.gov.nt.ca/early-childhood-and-school-services/early-childhood/language-nests|title = Language Nests|date = |accessdate = March 28, 2015|website = Northwest Territories: Education, Culture, and Employment|publisher = Government of the Northwest Territories|last = |first = }}</ref>
==In Estonia==
There is only one language nest for [[Võro language|Võro]] working three days a week in [[Haanja]] and several initiatives, so called "language nest days" (''keelepesäpäiv'') that are working one day in week in 18 different kindergartens of Võro area. Võro language nest initiatives are organised by [[Võro Institute]].
==In Finland==
There are language nests for [[Inari Sami language|Inari Sámi]], [[Skolt Sami language|Skolt Sami]], and the Karelian languages in Finland.

[[File:JosephHoweProvinceHouseNovaScotia.png|thumb|500px|Libel Trial of [[Joseph Howe]], Supreme Court (current Legislative Library), [[Province House (Nova Scotia)]] by [[Louis-Philippe Hébert]]]]
The '''Libel trial of Joseph Howe''' was a court case heard 2 March 1835 in which newspaper editor [[Joseph Howe]] was charged with [[seditious libel]] by civic politicians in [[Nova Scotia]]. Howe's victory in court was considered monumental at the time. In the first issue of the ''Novascotian'' following the acquittal, Howe claimed that "the press of Nova-Scotia is Free."<ref name=beck39>Beck (1974), 39.</ref> Scholars, such as [[John Ralston Saul]], have argued that Howe's libel victory established the fundamental basis for the freedom of the press in Canada.<ref>Saul, p. 10; Kesterton, pp. 21–23.</ref> Historian Barry Cahill writes that the trial was significant in colonial legal history because it was a long delayed replay of the [[John Peter Zenger|Zenger case]] (1734).<ref>Cahill, p. 563</ref>
== Background == {{History of Nova Scotia}} During the year 1834, Howe was starting to attract attention to himself due to his strong independent viewpoints in his editorials in the ''[[Novascotian]]'', the Government was starting to take notice.<ref>Chisholm, 7.</ref> Howe had eventually reached his breaking point and in late 1834 wrote in the ''Novascotian'' that he was going to start a campaign in the interest of bringing to light the wrongful actions of government.<ref>Rosner, 11.</ref> On January 1, 1835, the final piece of this campaign was published in the ''Novascotian'', a letter signed "The People".<ref>Beck (1974), 31.</ref>
This letter accused the magistrates of, "reprehensible irresponsibility, incompetence, and self-interestedness in the conduct of their responsibilities."<ref>Campbell, 80.</ref> Specifically, in the letter [[Joseph Howe]] accused Halifax politicians and police of pocketing £30,000 over a thirty-year period. Due to the letter being published, Howe was put on trial for [[seditious libel]], being charged with "seditiously contriving, devising, and intending to stir up and incite discontent and sedition among His Majesty's subjects."<ref name=rosner12>Rosner, 12.</ref> The crime of seditious libel had only been defined 200 years prior to the time of Howe's trial and was seen by many as an unfair crime as it could be as broad or as specific as the court chose."<ref>[[Seditious libel]]</ref>
==Trial== The trial took place in the present day library of [[Province House (Nova Scotia)]] and the judge in the case was [[Brenton Halliburton]]. Howe represented himself in the trial as no lawyer would defend him. Howe used as the basis of his argument the [[Libel Act 1792]].<ref>Cahill, 1996, p. 360</ref> He presented for six and a quarter hours addressing the jury, citing case after case of civic corruption. He spoke eloquently about the importance of press freedom, urging jurors "to leave an unshackled press as a legacy to your children." Even though the judge instructed the jury to find Howe guilty, jurors took only ten minutes to acquit him.<ref name=rosner12/>
== Legacy ==
The victory of Howe in the court was considered monumental at the time. In the first issue of the ''Novascotian'' following the acquittal, Howe claimed that "the press of Nova-Scotia is Free."<ref name=beck39>Beck (1974), 39.</ref> Some scholars have argued that Howe's libel victory changed little in the strict legal sense, however, other scholars insist that the case established the fundamental basis for the freedom of the press in Canada.<ref>Saul, p. 10</ref>
Joseph Howe scholar J. M. Beck argues that Howe was victorious convincing a jury that the libel law was unjust, however, his trial had no immediate effect on changing the civil or criminal code with respect to libel. Beck asserts that the idea that Howe's trial contributed to the freedom of the press in Canada is a, "myth that has little basis in fact".<ref name=beck39/><ref name=campbell114>Campbell, 114.</ref> In fact, eight years after the trial, Howe's successor at the ''Novascotian'' Richard Nugent was charged and found guilty of libel (1843).<ref name=beck39/> Nugent was imprisoned due to his inability to pay damages.<ref name=beck39/> Beck also notes that in 1843, the British Parliament passed a law that allowed the accused to use truth of the libel as their defence, which led to freedom of the press.<ref name=beck39/>
Scholars have agreed with the strict legal sense of Beck's argument, however, scholar Cecil Rosner states, "The Howe trial is noteworthy more for its symbolic effect than any legal precedent it may have set...charges of [[sedition]] have largely disappeared [but] journalists across the country continue to face civil libel threats...".<ref name=rosner12/><ref>Rosner argues that Canadian law restricts the sources that journalists may use, and despite the introduction of Freedom of the Press in the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] courts are still limiting press rights if they deem it necessary; Quebec does not accept truth as an appropriate defense for a libel case; and while journalists in the United States of America enjoy the ability to criticize their elected representatives without risk of prosecution, Canadian journalists do not have the same protection. Rosner concludes that "...more victories remain to be won".</ref>
Lyndsay M. Campbell argues that the trial did eventually change the law. Howe was the first in Nova Scotia to argue [[Intention (criminal law)|intent]] before a jury.<ref name=campbell114/> Campbell also notes that while Howe's defence did not persuade the presiding judge, it was a defense that would be used by lawyers in future cases.<ref>Campbell, 115.</ref> Howe changed how the law was perceived by both the legal profession and by the general public.<ref>Campbell, 115-116</ref> The timing of the trial was crucial to the lasting effect it had on Canada. It occurred when the number of newspapers was growing rapidly and they were all pushing their own boundaries when it came to political commentary.<ref name=campbell116>Campbell, 116.</ref> Howe's trial removed the fear of prosecution from these newspapers for having political commentary of their own, as Campbell puts it, "The sense of what was possible had changed."<ref name=campbell116/>
John Ralston Saul states that by, "...winning his acquittal, Howe established the fundamental ideas, principles, and shapes of freedom of speech and freedom of the press in Canada."<ref name=saul10>Saul, 10.</ref> Saul acknowledges that, in terms of freedom of speech and freedom of the press, the laws have regressed and progressed multiple times since Howe's trial. Saul argues that Howe created the, "...intellectual foundation of how we still struggle to solidify and to widen the nature of freedom of speech and of the press."<ref name=saul10/> Saul states that Howe's trial also had a significant influence on the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]]. He argues there is a clear link between Howe's defense and lines 9 and 10 of the Charter, which refer to freedom of speech and freedom of the press.<ref>Saul, 11.</ref> Saul also references many public leaders across Canada since Howe's trial who were influenced by him, such as Fred Dickson who was the leader of the [[1919 Winnipeg Strike]] on trial for seditious libel, who read Howe's defence was their own to, "speak from an ethical center in their own public lives."<ref>Saul, 14.</ref>
== Film == In 1961, the [[National Film Board of Canada]] (NFB) produced a 28-minute film about the trial entitled ''Joseph Howe: The Tribune of Nova Scotia''.<ref name=nfb>{{cite web| url=http://www.nfb.ca/film/joseph_howe_tribune_nova_scotia/| title=Joseph Howe: The Tribune of Nova Scotia| publisher=NFB| accessdate=2014-09-16}}</ref><ref name=imdb>{{cite web| url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0223579/| title=Joseph Howe: The Tribune of Nova Scotia| publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]| accessdate=2014-09-16}}</ref>

{{Aftermath of World War II in Yugoslavia}} {{refimprove|date=May 2012}} [[File:M 023.JPG|thumb|A cross in Macelj]] In May and June 1945, at the [[end of World War II in Europe]], the forests near [[Macelj]], a village in northern [[Croatia]], were the location where a large number of persons who were [[Independent State of Croatia|soldiers of NDH or closely associated with NDH]], were shot by soldiers of the [[Partisans (Yugoslavia)|Yugoslav army (the Partisans)]]. This was part of the events referred to as the [[Bleiburg tragedy]]. ==Events== In 1992, after Croatia became independent, 1163 bodies were excavated from 23 mass graves in the region, leaving around 130 possible mass grave locations unexplored.<ref name="vecernji-2012">{{cite news | url = http://www.vecernji.hr/regije/macelj-gora-zlocina-clanak-410508 | newspaper = [[Večernji list]] | language = Croatian | title = Macelj - gora zločina! | date = 2012-05-16 | accessdate = 2012-06-01}}</ref>{{Better source|date=October 2017}} [[Genetic fingerprinting|DNA analysis]] was conducted on a few hundred of them. The names of identified persons were not officially published, but it is clear that they were victims of a mass execution. A large number of the bodies were dropped into the area's many pits, making it difficult to locate all casualties. Further investigation on this issue was not conducted, and final conclusions about the excavations cannot be drawn yet. Some of those executions have been investigated, but no one has ever been prosecuted.
Among those executed in Macelj were 25 Catholic priests from the [[Franciscan monastery of Široki Brijeg]] which were temporarily hidden in nearby [[Krapina]].<ref name ="Hršak at Jutarnji">{{cite news | url = http://www.jutarnji.hr/dogadjaji_dana/clanak/art-2008,2,9,,108130.jl | newspaper = [[Jutarnji list]] | language = Croatian | title = Stjepan Hršak: Nisam sudjelovao u likvidaciji 25 svećenika u Macelju |trans-title=Stjepan Hršak: I did not take part in liquidation of 25 priests at Macelj | date = 2008-02-09 | accessdate = 2012-06-01}}</ref> In 2008, the [[Croatian Ministry of the Interior]] launched an investigation into Stjepan Hršak's possible involvement in that event.<ref name ="Hršak at Jutarnji"/>
Reburial of excavated bodies in 2005 was followed by public mass led by [[Josip Bozanić|Cardinal Josip Bozanić]], at the time [[Archbishop of Zagreb]].

'''Macroeconomic populism''' is a term coined by [[Rudi Dornbusch]] and [[Sebastian Edwards]] in a 1990 paper.<ref name="paper">{{cite journal |title=Macroeconomic Populism |first=Rudiger |last=Dornbusch |first2=Sebastian |last2=Edwards |journal=[[Journal of Development Economics]] |volume=32 |issue=2 |year=1990 |pages=247–277 |doi=10.1016/0304-3878(90)90038-D }}</ref> The term refers to the policies by many [[Latin American]] administrations by which [[government spending]] and [[real wages]] increase in a non-sustainable way leading to [[inflation]], then [[stagflation]] and ultimately an [[economic collapse]] that drops real wages to lower than they were before the [[populist]] period began. The paper cites as examples [[Salvador Allende]] in [[Chile]] (1970–1973), and [[Alan García]] first term in [[Peru]] (1985–1990). In 1991, Dornbusch and Edwards edited a book titled ''The [[Macroeconomics]] of Populism in Latin America'' which analyzed more cases like [[Argentina]] between 1973 and 1976, [[Mexico]] between 1970 and 1982, and [[Brazil]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/M/bo3684436.html|title=The Macroeconomics of Populism in Latin America}}</ref>
In 2014, [[Paul Krugman]] cited Argentina's policies under [[Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner]] and [[Venezuela]] as new cases of macroeconomic populism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/01/macroeconomic-populism-returns/|title=Macroeconomic Populism Returns|work=Paul Krugman Blog|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2017/01/29/the-macroeconomics-of-reality-tv-populism/|title=The Macroeconomics of Reality-TV Populism|work=Paul Krugman Blog|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en}}</ref> In 2014, during a lecture he said he did not endorse the attacks on Argentina nor what it looks to him as a "somewhat out of control fiscal and monetary policy."<ref>November 18, 2014. TN. Palabras + Palabras -.</ref>
== Formal definition == The definition of macroeconomic populism in the original paper states as follows: "Macroeconomic populism is an approach to economics that emphasizes growth and income distribution and deemphasizes the risks of inflation and deficit finance, external constraints and the reaction of economic agents to aggressive non-market policies."<ref name="paper"/>
== Phases == The start of a populist cycle is generally after a stabilization program. The economy has idle capacity and the budget and external balance have room left for a expansionary policy. # '''Phase I''' includes a high increase in public spending and an increase in real wages and employment. Gross domestic product increases and there is low impact on inflation. Shortages are alleviated by imports. There is a reduction in reserves or debt default. # '''Phase II''' includes an increase in inflation, although wages keep up. Bottlenecks lead to price and exchange controls. The budget deficit greatly increases as a result of subsidies. The economy runs into [[stagflation]]. # '''Phase III''' is characterized by shortages, extreme acceleration of inflation (possibly [[hyperinflation]]), and capital flight. A decline in tax revenue combined with high inflation results in an increase in the budget deficit ([[Olivera–Tanzi effect]]). A stabilization attempt by reducing subsidies and devaluation leads to a drop in real wages. As the paper states "politics become unstable. It becomes clear that the government has lost." # '''Phase IV''': A new government implements orthodox policies to stabilize the economy. Once the economy is stabilized real wages will have fallen lower than before Phase I began.

Manipur''' is an [[Maoist Armed Revolutionary Party]]{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/guwahati/KCPs-ultra-Left-turn-worries-Manipur/articleshow/10016542.cms |title=KCP's ultra-Left turn worries Manipur |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |first=Caesar |last=Mandal |location=Kolkata |date=17 September 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2014}} [[communist party]] in [[Manipur]] which aims "to establish a [[communist society]] through armed revolutionary war."{{cite news |url=http://www.theshillongtimes.com/2011/09/21/maoism-in-manipur/ |title=Maoism in Manipur |newspaper=[[The Shillong Times]] |date=21 September 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714173939/http://www.theshillongtimes.com/2011/09/21/maoism-in-manipur/ |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }} The Maoist Communist Party of Manipur also intends at liberating the people of Manipur from whom they view as "[[Colonialism|colonial]] India." ==Background and ideology== The Maoist Communist Party of Manipur (MCPM) was formed in August 2011 after amended its constitution in accordance with [[Marxism–Leninism–Maoism]] and decided to take up M–L–M as the party's guiding ideology. After the party's first conference which was held in the [[North-East India|North-East]], the party issued a statement declaring that the MCPM has decided to carry out the [[New Democratic Revolution]] and would conduct the [[protracted people's war]] in collaboration with the other "Maoist revolutionary parties." ==Organisation== The Coordinator of the Standing Committee of MCPM is Kyonghan,{{cite news |url=http://imphaltimes.com/maoist-releases-red-thunder/ |archiveurl=http://archive.imphaltimes.com/maoist-releases-red-thunder/ |title=Maoist releases "Red Thunder" |newspaper=Imphal Times |location=Imphal |date=30 September 2013 |accessdate=13 June 2014 |archivedate=July 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://manipurtimes.com/news-article/the-peoples-chronicle-news/item/2250-maoist-communist-party-manipur-for-a-common-platform-of-maoists |title=Maoist Communist Party Manipur for a common platform of Maoists |publisher=Manipur Times |date=9 August 2013 |accessdate=30 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810162159/http://manipurtimes.com/news-article/the-peoples-chronicle-news/item/2250-maoist-communist-party-manipur-for-a-common-platform-of-maoists |archivedate=10 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }} and its [[Chairman#Vice chairman and deputy chairman|vice chairperson]] is Mang Ulen San.{{cite news |url=http://thepeopleschronicle.in/?p=26230 |title=Maoist to launch monthly journal on Irabot Day |publisher=The People's Chronicle |date=30 September 2013 |accessdate=13 June 2014}} The Publicity and Propaganda secretary is Nonglen Meitei.{{cite news |url=http://imphaltimes.com/may-day-wishes-from-maoist-communist-party-manipur/ |archiveurl=http://archive.imphaltimes.com/may-day-wishes-from-maoist-communist-party-manipur/ |title=May Day wishes from Maoist Communist Party, Manipur |work=Imphal Times |location=Imphal |date=30 April 2013 |accessdate=9 June 2014 |archivedate=July 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://imphaltimes.com/news/item/342-maoist-highlights-foul-play-in-text-book-printing-by-bosem |title=Maoists highlights foul play in text book printing by BOSEM |work=Imphal Times |location=Imphal |date=9 July 2014 |accessdate=29 July 2014}} The MCPM has alleged that Chingranglen Meitei, who was working as the [[General Secretary]] of the party was ferret out and arrested by a squad of the Indian armed forces, while he was approaching towards his comrades.{{cite news |url=http://www.manipurtimes.com/news-article/the-peoples-chronicle-brief-news/item/9201-mcpm-gen-secy-arrested |title=MCPM gen secy arrested |publisher=Manipur Times |location=Imphal |accessdate=9 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714152548/http://www.manipurtimes.com/news-article/the-peoples-chronicle-brief-news/item/9201-mcpm-gen-secy-arrested |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }} On 20 May 2014, the MCPM released an official statement that the party was not being able to trace Chingranglen Meitei since the time of his alleged abduction [by Indian personnel], and has no clue about his "whereabouts."{{cite news |url=http://www.nagalandpost.com/channelnews/regional/RegionalNews.aspx?news=TkVXUzEwMDA2MDA3Mg%3D%3D |title=MCPM general secretary remained untraceable |newspaper=Nagaland Post |location=Imphal |date=21 May 2014 |accessdate=29 July 2014}} A united revolution is still a failure in Manipur due to cerebrated design of those trying to create division amongst indigenous community inhabiting in the state from time immemorial.| Nonglen Meitei, in 2012{{cite news |url=http://thepeopleschronicle.in/?p=7037 |title=Maoists distributes seeds to farmers |publisher=The People's Chronicle |date=30 December 2012 |accessdate=11 June 2014}} ===Central Military Commission=== The MCPM structured the party's [[Central Military Commission]] (CMC) on 21 September 2012, and Taibanglen Meitei is also the CMC's chairperson.{{cite news |url=http://imphaltimes.com/maoist-communist-party-greets-people-first-anniversary-npm/ |archiveurl=http://archive.imphaltimes.com/maoist-communist-party-greets-people-first-anniversary-npm/ |title=Maoist Communist Party greets people on the first anniversary of NPM |work=Imphal Times |location=Imphal |date=21 September 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2014 |archivedate=July 2014}} ===New People's Militia=== On 21 September 2012,{{cite news |url=http://www.manipurtimes.com/news-article/the-peoples-chronicle-news/item/3266-maoist-manipur-extends-greetings-to-people |title=Maoist Manipur extends greetings to people |publisher=Manipur Times |accessdate=29 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810063033/http://www.manipurtimes.com/news-article/the-peoples-chronicle-news/item/3266-maoist-manipur-extends-greetings-to-people |archivedate=10 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }} the MCPM also constituted an armed wing in the guidance of its CMC, known as "New People's Militia," whose objective is to muster a "People's Guerilla Army." The party's chairperson has voiced that the New People's Militia (NPM) was established in the light of [[People's war|Mao's Theory of Three Magic Weapons]], and it aims at "carrying out offensive against colonial forces to regain Manipur people's freedom status." The party believes that despite of being at the "initial stage," it is still "capable of launching offensives in mobile," and is looking forward to raise the NPM's strength, eyeing to "effectively launch positional war with the enemy [Indian [[State (polity)|State]]]." ==Legal status== The MCPM is a banned organisation. ==Relations with other insurgents== The [[Communist Party of India (Maoist)]] has termed the establishment of MCPM as "an event of historical significance in the annals of the history of revolution in South-Asia" and has stated that "it would fight shoulder to shoulder with them [MCPM] in the fight against the common enemy – the Indian [[State (polity)|State]]."{{cite news |url=http://imphaltimes.com/central-committee-cpi-maoist-acknowledge-maoist-communist-party-of-manipur-existence-it-news-imphal-may-3-the-central-committee-cpi-maoist-extends-its-heartfelt-revolutionary-greetings-to-the/ |archiveurl=http://archive.imphaltimes.com/central-committee-cpi-maoist-acknowledge-maoist-communist-party-of-manipur-existence-it-news-imphal-may-3-the-central-committee-cpi-maoist-extends-its-heartfelt-revolutionary-greetings-to-the/ |title=Central Committee, CPI (Maoist) acknowledge Maoist Communist Party of Manipur existence |work=Imphal Times |location=Imphal |date=3 May 2013 |accessdate=9 June 2014 |archivedate=July 2014}} The CPI (Maoist) had also maintained close ties with the KCP (Maoist) and the [[People's Liberation Army of Manipur]] in the past. The KCP (Maoist), in November 2010, pledged "support" to "Indian Maoists."{{cite news |url=http://lite.epaper.timesofindia.com/mobile.aspx?article=yes&pageid=8&edlabel=TOIKM&mydateHid=18-09-2011&pubname=&edname=&articleid=Ar00801&format=&publabel=TOI |title=NE rebels embrace Maoist ideology |first=Caesar |last=Mandal |location=Kolkata |publisher=[[Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd.]] |date= 18 September 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2014}} {{Quotation|World [[Proletarian Revolution]] would have a new lease of life if Maoist groups operating in Asia worked together on a common platform by setting up an Asian Maoist Coordinating Committee.| Taibanglen Meitei, on the occasion of second anniversary of the MCPM}} ==Election boycott== The MCPM [[boycott]]ed the [[Manipur Legislative Assembly election, 2012]] and banned "all election related functions" in the state because the party believed that the "assembly elections in Manipur would never bring welfare to the people nor bring any development" and would just amplify the "Indian system of rule."{{cite news |url=http://www.samachar.com/maoist-communist-party-manipur-boycotts-general-election-lm2iM5bggea.html |title=Maoist Communist Party Manipur boycotts general election |work=Imphal Free Press |publisher=Sify |date=26 December 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140615083258/http://www.samachar.com/maoist-communist-party-manipur-boycotts-general-election-lm2iM5bggea.html |archivedate=15 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }} In April 2014, the MCPM called for a "political strike" in Manipur{{cite news |url=http://www.nagalandpost.com/channelnews/regional/RegionalNews.aspx?news=TkVXUzEwMDA1NzM5MA%3D%3D |title=MCPM announces 'political strike' to boycott LS polls |newspaper=[[Nagaland Post]] |date=2 April 2014 |accessdate=13 June 2014}} and boycotted the [[Indian general election, 2014 (Manipur)|Indian general election, 2014 in the state]], saying that "the Indian election is not needed." The ban imposed on the Indian general election, 2014 in Manipur by the MCPM along with the United Revolutionary Front, and the Kuki National Army (Indian) affected the [[political campaigning]] of the candidates, and they had to drop their door–to–door campaign while several candidates avoided to visit their [[constituencies]] as a violent armed action was expected beyond doubt if "electioneering" would have been attempted in Manipur.{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/candidates-unable-to-campaign-despite-protection/article5853238.ece |title=Candidates unable to campaign despite protection |first=Iboyaima |last=Laithangbam |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |location=Imphal |date=31 March 2014 |accessdate=13 June 2014}} The MCPM had urged its comrades to closely and alertly monitor the electoral campaign of the political parties and their contestants, and to execute strategies to pester the election process while avoiding to engender inconvenience to the people. {{Quotation|Conducting India's elections in Manipur was nothing but a deliberate attempt to divert the mind of the people of the [[Constituent state|state]] from the armed struggle for liberation and to portray it (liberation struggle) in the wrong sense.| Maoist Communist Party of Manipur, in 2014}} ==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Abhizeet Asom]] * [[Paresh Baruah]] * [[Insurgency in Northeast India]] * [[Operation Green Hunt]] * [[Operation Steeplechase]] * [[List of Naxalite and Maoist groups in India]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=August 2013}}{{globalize/United States|date=May 2016}}}} A '''military operation plan''' (also called a '''war plan''' before [[World War II]]) is a formal [[plan]] for [[military|military armed forces]], their [[military organization]]s and units to conduct operations, as drawn up by commanders within the [[combat operations process]] in achieving objectives before or during a [[war|conflict]]. Military plans are generally produced in accordance with the [[military doctrine]] of the troops involved.
[[Plan XVII]] and the [[Schlieffen Plan]] are examples of [[World War I]] military plans. The [[United States]] developed a famous color-coded set of war plans in the early 20th century; see [[United States color-coded war plans]].
Military plans often have [[code name]]s.
==United States==
In the [[United States armed forces|U.S. military]], an Operation Plan (OPLAN) is a complete and detailed plan for conducting [[joint warfare|joint]] military operations.<ref>Joint Publication 5-0. ''[http://www.dtic.mil/doctrine/new_pubs/jp5_0.pdf Joint Operation Planning]''. 26 December 2006. Accessed 21 August 2010.</ref> An OPLAN is developed by the Combatant Commander (CCDR) of a [[Unified Combatant Command]] in response to actual or potential situations for which military operations may be required. An OPLAN is executed when the commander issues an [[operations order]] (OPORD), or when the [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] (CJCS) issues an execute order (EXORD) at the direction of the [[United States Secretary of Defense]] (Secdef) to implement a decision by the [[President of the United States|President]] to initiate military operations. A concept plan (CONPLAN) is an operation plan in concept form, often lacking the level of details normally found in other military plans.
Among publicly known U.S. Operations Plans are two which address possible events on the Korean Peninsula, [[OPLAN 5027]], the U.S. general war plan which has been regularly updated since at least the mid-1990s, and [[OPLAN 5029]], a plan catering to a sudden collapse of the [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]]. [[OPLAN 8044]] and [[OPLAN 8010]] are both successor plans to the [[Single Integrated Operational Plan]], the general plan for nuclear war from 1961 to 2003. [[U.S. Central Command OPLAN 1003-98|OPLAN 1003-98]] was the pre-2002 plan for war with [[Iraq]].
==North Atlantic Treaty Organization== In [[NATO|North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)]] the successful planning of multinational military operations requires common doctrine. This doctrine is documented in Allied Joint Publication (AJP) five, which is aimed primarily at those engaged in operational-level planning, specifically commanders and staffs employed in joint force command headquarters and component command headquarters. It describes the fundamental aspects of planning joint operations at the operational level and provides an overarching framework of the key planning principles, considerations and process steps that are followed in operational-level planning.<ref name="AJP5">{{cite web |url=https://nso.nato.int/nso/zPublic/ap/AJP-5%20E.pdf |title=Allied Joint Publication 5 - Allied Joint Doctrine for Operational-Level Planning |date=June 2013|publisher=NATO|access-date=21 May 2017|ID=AJP-5}}</ref>
